Four {@item javelin|phb|javelins}.

default: (a) {@item chain mail|phb} or (b) {@item leather armor|phb}, {@item longbow|phb}, {@item arrows (20)|phb|20 arrows}.
(a) a {@filter martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} and a {@item shield|phb} or (b) two {@filter martial weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon}.

entries: {@b Arcane Tradition:} Choose your arcane tradition at 3rd-level, not 1st.
You don't gain a spellbook automatically as a result of multiclassing, so make sure that you have the means to acquire one.

classFeature.name: Rage
entries: You are able to enter a rage that pushes your physical strength beyond its normal limits.
You can spend a bonus action to enter a rage that lasts for up to 1 minute. While raging, you gain the following benefits if you are not wearing heavy armor:

items: {@b Brutal Strength:} You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
{@b Rage Damage:} When you make a melee weapon attack using Strength, you gain a bonus to the damage roll as shown in the {@i Rage Damage} column of the Class Features (Barbarian) table.
{@b Thick Skin:} You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from both magical and non-magical sources.

entries: You can use this feature a limited number of times, as shown in the {@i Rages} column of the Class Features (Barbarian) table. You recover all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Spellcasting
entries: During a rage, you can't cast spells or concentrate on magic. If you are concentrating on a spell when you enter a rage, that concentration ends immediately.

entries.name: Magic Items:
entries: Some items allow you to trigger magic effects—scrolls, wands, etc. You can activate these items unless it is specified that you are casting a spell.

entries.name: Ending a Rage
entries: Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if any of the following situations apply:

items: {@b Blackout:} You are knocked unconscious.
{@b Passive Aggression:} Your turn ends and either (a) you haven't attacked a hostile creature or (b) you haven't taken any damage since the end of your previous turn.
{@b Serenity Now:} You spend a bonus action on your turn to end your rage.

entries.name: Unarmed Attacks
entries: An unarmed attack (such as a punch, kick, headbutt, etc) counts as a melee weapon attack—it gains the benefit of your rage damage.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: While you are not wearing any armor, your armor class equals 10 + your Constitution modifier + either (a) your Dexterity modifier or (b) your Intelligence modifier—you may choose which modifier to use. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Brutality
entries: You have a number of brutality points, as shown in the {@i Brutality Points} column of the Class Features (Barbarian) table. You can spend brutality to overwhelm your enemies with brutalities—and you may learn other applications from your Primal Path.
You recover all expended brutality points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Brutalities
entries: At 1st-level, you have mastered two brutalities of your choice. You master additional brutalities as you gain more barbarian levels, as show in the {@i Brutalities Known} column of the Class Features (Barbarian) table.
Once per turn, you may spend one brutality point to use one of your mastered brutalities.

entries.name: Replacing a Brutality:
entries: Whenever you finish a long rest, you may replace one of your mastered brutalities with another brutality.

entries.name: Saving Throws:
entries: Use your Strength modifier to determine the saving throw DC for your brutalities.

entries.name: Cleave
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can attempt to damage another nearby creature. Choose a creature that is (a) within 5 ft of the original target and (b) within your reach. If the original attack roll would hit the second creature, that creature takes {@damage 1d6} damage. The damage is of the same type dealt by the original attack, and can't exceed the total damage dealt by the original attack.

entries.name: Greater Cleave:
entries: (5th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 2d8}.

entries.name: Superior Cleave:
entries: (9th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 2d8} to {@damage 3d10}.

entries.name: Grab
entries: When you hit an adjacent creature with an opportunity attack and you have at least one hand free, you can attempt to grab hold of the creature. If the creature is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw—the target may choose which. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition grappled} by you.

entries.name: Greater Grab:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this brutality against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Grab:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this brutality against Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Headbutt
entries: When you hit an adjacent creature with a melee weapon attack, you can use a bonus action to attempt to knock the creature down. If the target is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you knock the target {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Greater Headbutt:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this brutality against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Headbutt:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this brutality against Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Kick
entries: When you hit an adjacent creature with a melee weapon attack, you can try to kick it away from you. If the target is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you knock the creature back up to 10 ft.

entries.name: Greater Kick:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this brutality against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Kick:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this brutality against Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Roar
entries: When you hit an adjacent creature with a melee weapon attack, you can attempt to frighten the creature. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it is {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Greater Roar:
entries: (5th-level) You can target one additional creature that is within 5 ft of you.

entries.name: Superior Roar:
entries: (9th-level) You can target one additional creature that is within 10 ft of you.

entries.name: Smash
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can momentarily weaken its defenses. Until the start of your next turn, the next attack roll made against the creature by an attacker other than you has advantage.

entries.name: Greater Smash:
entries: (5th-level) The creature grants advantage to the next two attack rolls made against it before the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Superior Smash:
entries: (9th-level) The creature grants advantage to the next three attack rolls made against it before the start of your next turn.

classFeature.name: Primal Path
entries: A fierce rage burns deep in your heart—a white-hot fire that can push you above and beyond your mortal limitations. But without control, your greatest strength can become your greatest weakness.
To help you master your rage—for good or ill—you must choose a {@i Primal Path}. Walk this path to discover your own unique strength and how to wield it.
You gain features from your Primal Path at 1st, 3rd, 6th, and 10th-level.

entries.name: Primal Brutalities
entries: You gain access to four unique brutalities from your Primal Path. Add these to your list of brutality options.

classFeature.name: Survival Instincts
entries: Choose one of the following options.

entries.name: Danger Sense
entries: You have advantage on Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see—such as traps, spells, and attacks. To gain this benefit, you can't be {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, or {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Primal Knowledge
entries: You become proficient in your choice of two of the following skills: {@skill Animal Handling}, {@skill Medicine}, {@skill Nature}, {@skill Perception}, or {@skill Survival}. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of those skills.

classFeature.name: Reckless Attack
entries: Before you make your first attack on your turn, you can choose to attack recklessly. You have advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls using Strength until the end of your turn. But in return, all attack rolls made against you have advantage until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Reckless Brutalities:
entries: While you are being reckless, you can't use a mastered brutality unless that brutality specifies otherwise.

classFeature.name: Primal Path Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your Primal Path.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Feral Movement
entries: Choose one of the following options.

entries.name: Fast Mover
entries: Your natural speed increases by 10 ft while you're not wearing heavy armor. If you have multiple forms of innate movement—such as climbing, flying, swimming, etc—each movement speed increases by 10 ft.

entries.name: Unnatural Movement:
entries: If you gain a movement speed through an external effect—such as an item, feature, or spell—that speed doesn't increase with this feature.

entries.name: Leap
entries: When a creature ends its turn within 15 ft of you, you can spend your reaction to move up to half your speed to a space closer to the creature. This movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks.

classFeature.name: Greater Brutalities
entries: At 5th level, your mastered brutalities become more effective.

classFeature.name: Primal Path Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature from your Primal Path.

classFeature.name: Feral Instinct
entries: You have advantage on your initiative rolls. If you are surprised at the beginning of combat and aren't incapacitated, you can act normally on your first turn—but only if you enter your rage before doing anything else on that turn.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Brutal Critical
entries: You can roll one additional weapon damage die when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

entries.name: Brutality:
entries: Whenever you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with a critical hit from a melee attack, you regain 1 expended brutality point.

classFeature.name: Superior Brutalities
entries: At 9th level, you have reached the full potential of your mastered brutalities.

classFeature.name: Mastered Rage
entries: When you enter a rage, you may choose to master it. Each time you do so, pick one of the following options—you gain this in addition to the other features granted by your rage ability.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Fast
entries: For the duration of your mastered rage, your natural speed increases by 10 ft. If you have multiple forms of innate movement—such as climbing, flying, swimming, etc—each movement speed increases by 10 ft.

entries.name: Fast Mover:
entries: If you have the {@i Fast Mover} trait, this benefit stacks.

entries.name: Fierce
entries: For the duration of your mastered rage, double the damage bonus granted by your {@i Rage Damage}.

entries.name: Focused
entries: For the duration of your mastered rage, you may cast and concentrate on spells as normal.

entries.name: Frightening
entries: For the duration of your mastered rage, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses {@skill Intimidation} or {@skill Athletics}.

classFeature.name: Primal Path Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature from your Primal Path.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You gain the ability to cast magic spells using words of power and musical notes.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st-level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the bard spell list. You learn additional bard cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the {@i Cantrips Known} column of the Class Features (Bard) table.

entries.name: Replacing Known Cantrips:
entries: When you gain a bard level, you can choose one of the bard cantrips you know and replace it with another cantrip from the bard spell list.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Class Features (Bard) table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st-level and higher. To cast one of your spells, you must spend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-level and Higher
entries: At 1st-level, you know four 1st-level spells of your choice from the bard spell list. The {@i Spells Known} column of the Class Features (Bard) table shows when you learn more bard spells of your choice. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Replacing Known Spells:
entries: When you gain a bard level, you may choose one of the bard spells you know and replace it with another spell from the bard spell list. This new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your bard spells. Use your Charisma modifier to determine the saving throw DC or attack modifier for a bard spell you cast.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast any bard spell you know as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You use a musical instrument as a spellcasting focus for your bard spells.

classFeature.name: Composition
entries: You have a number of composition points, as shown in the {@i Composition Points} column of the Class Features (Bard) table. You can spend composition to inspire and revitalize your allies—and you may learn other applications from your Bard College.
You recover all expended composition points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Bardic Inspiration
entries: You can use your compositions to inspire other creatures with stirring words and music.

Spend one bonus action and one point of composition to choose one creature other than yourself that is (a) within 60 feet of you and (b) can hear you. The chosen creature gains one {@i Bardic Inspiration} die—a {@dice d6}.

{@b Being Inspired:} A creature with {@i Bardic Inspiration} has 10 minutes in which to choose to roll the die and add the number rolled to one ability check, attack roll, or saving throw it makes. The creature can wait until after it rolls before deciding to use the {@i Bardic Inspiration} die, but it must do so before the GM says whether the roll succeeds or fails.
Once the die is rolled, it is spent. A creature can have only one Bardic Inspiration die at a time.

items: {@b Growing Inspiration:} The {@i Bardic Inspiration} die grows as you gain bard levels, as shown in the {@i Bardic Inspiration} column of the Class Features (Bard) table.

classFeature.name: Bard College
entries: Art demands an audience, and bards are nothing if not gregarious. To perfect their art, bards seek others out to swap songs and stories, boast of their accomplishments, and share their knowledge. Bards often form loose associations—their {@i colleges}—to facilitate their gatherings and preserve their traditions.
Whatever your background, this chapter introduces a variety of colleges for you to choose from. Define your bardic traditions and perfect your art.
Choose a Bard College. You gain features from your Bard College at 1st, 3rd, 6th, and 10th-level.

entries.name: Collegiate Pledges
entries: Each college has a set of three guiding principles—its {@i pledges}—that help to preserve bardic traditions. Respect these pledges to gain distinction from fellow bards.

entries.name: Collegiate Distinction:
entries: If you make a notable effort while honoring your collegiate pledges, you may gain a mark of {@i distinction}.

During a long rest, you can spend one mark of distinction to share songs with another bard and replace one of your known bard spells (including cantrips) with another spell from the bard spell list. The new spell must be of the same spell level as the one you replace.

entries.name: Collegiate Inspiration
entries: At 1st-level, you gain a unique way to use your {@i Bardic Inspiration} class feature from your Bard College.

classFeature.name: Jack of All Trades
entries: You can add half your proficiency bonus, rounded down, to any ability check you make that doesn't already include your proficiency bonus.

classFeature.name: Song of Rest
entries: During a short rest, you can help to revitalize your allies by playing a soothing song or telling an inspiring story.
If you—or any friendly creature who can hear your performance—regain hit points by spending one or more Hit Dice, each creature regains an extra {@dice 1d6} hit points.

entries.name: Greater Song of Rest:
entries: At 9th-level, the extra hit points regained increases from {@dice 1d6} to {@dice 1d8}.

entries.name: Composed Song of Rest
entries: When you begin a {@i Song of Rest}, you can spend composition to increase the bonus hit points granted.
For each point of composition you spend, increase the die size of your song by one step (to a maximum of {@dice 1d12}).

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: Choose two skills in which you are proficient. You gain expertise in these skills, doubling your proficiency bonus for any ability check you make that uses either skill.

entries.name: Greater Expertise:
entries: At 10th-level, choose two additional skills in which you are proficient—you gain expertise in these skills also.

classFeature.name: Bard College Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your Bard College.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Countercharm
entries: As an action, you start a performance that lasts until the end of your next turn. During that time, you and any friendly creatures within 30 feet of you have advantage on saving throws against being frightened or charmed.
A creature must be able to hear you to benefit from this. The performance ends early if you are incapacitated, silenced, or if you voluntarily end it as a free action.

entries.name: Composed Countercharm
entries: As you begin to perform {@i Countercharm}, you may choose to alter your performance in the following ways.

items: {@b Fermata:} Spend one point of composition to extend the maximum duration of your Countercharm by one additional round.
{@b Forte:} Spend one point of composition to extend the maximum range of your Countercharm from 30 ft to 60 ft.
{@b Vivace:} Spend one point of composition to perform Countercharm as a bonus action instead of a full action.

classFeature.name: Bard College Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature from your Bard College.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Magical Secrets
entries: You learn two spells of your choice from any class. The spells don't have to be from the same class, but they must be a cantrip or of a spell level that you can cast.
The chosen spells count as bard spells for you and don't count against the number of bard spells you know.

classFeature.name: Chords of Power
entries: In your trained hands, a musical instrument can suddenly become a dangerous, sonic weapon.
As a bonus action, you start a performance that lasts for up to 1 minute. During this time, any musical instrument that you hold can be used as:

items: a. A {@i simple weapon} that deals {@damage 1d10} thunder damage.
b. A {@i simple ranged weapon} (range 60 ft) that deals {@damage 1d8} thunder damage.

entries: When you make an attack with a musical instrument, you can use your Charisma modifier (instead of Strength or Dexterity) for the attack and damage rolls.

items: {@b Curtain Call:} Your performance ends early if (a) you are incapacitated, (b) you are silenced, or (c) you voluntarily end it as a free action.
{@b Limited Run:} You may use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Bard College Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature from your Bard College.

classFeature.name: Divine Domain
entries: In a pantheon, every deity has influence over different aspects of mortal life. As a cleric, you choose one aspect of your deity's portfolio to emphasize.
For as long as you faithfully serve your deity's commandments, you are granted powers related to your divine domain.
Choose a Divine Domain. You gain features from your Divine Domain at 1st, 2nd, 6th, and 8th-level.

entries.name: Commandments
entries: Each domain has a set of three guiding principles—its {@i commandments}—that help to direct you in the service of your deity. Honor these commandments to gain—and maintain—the favor of your deity.

entries.name: Divine Favor:
entries: If you make a notable effort to honor a commandment, you may be blessed with {@i divine favor}. You can hold a maximum number of divine favors at one time equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum 1).
On your turn, as a free action, you may spend one point of divine favor to do one of the following:

items: {@b Gain Stamina:} Regain 1 expended hit die.
{@b Gain Power:} Regain 1 expended 1st-level spell slot.
{@b Twist Fate:} Reroll 1 ability check, attack roll, or saving throw. You must accept the second result.
{@b Cause Pain:} Reroll all damage dice of an attack you have just made. You may accept either result.
{@b Forgiveness:} Forgive one transgression you have made.

entries.name: Transgression:
entries: If your deity decides that you have actively broken or rejected a commandment, some of your divine power may be stripped away for a time.
Roll a {@dice d6} and check the {@i Transgression} table below to find out which class feature you lose access to. Reroll any result that doesn't fully apply to you.

entries.name: Penance:
entries: If you have transgressed, you will have to perform a penance to regain your deity's favor. The scale of this penance may vary depending on the severity of your transgression, but some common forms include:

items: {@b Donate:} You make a charitable donation of goods, coin, or time to a worthy cause.
{@b Confess:} You confess your transgression to a higher-ranking agent of your faith and are forgiven.
{@b Pray:} You spend a period of time in dedicated prayer to and worship of your deity.
{@b Serve:} You undertake a divine quest in the service of your deity and their domain.
{@b Sacrifice:} You give up something of significant personal value.

entries: If your penance is accepted, you regain one lost feature.

entries.name: Domain Spells
entries: Each domain has a list of spells—its domain spells—that you gain at the cleric levels noted in the domain description. Once you gain a domain spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day.
If you have a domain spell that doesn't appear on the cleric spell list, the spell is still a cleric spell for you.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You gain the ability to cast cleric spells by channeling divine power.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st-level, you know three cantrips of your choice from the cleric spell list. You learn additional cleric cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the {@i Cantrips Known} column of the Class Features (Cleric) table.

entries.name: Replacing Known Cantrips:
entries: When you gain a cleric level, you may choose one of the cleric cantrips you know and replace it with another cantrip from the cleric spell list.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Class Features (Cleric) table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st-level and higher. To cast one of your spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell cure wounds and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast cure wounds using either slot.

entries.name: Preparing Spells
entries: You prepare the list of cleric spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the cleric spell list.

entries.name: Preparing Your Spell List:
entries: Choose a number of cleric spells equal to your Wisdom modifier + your cleric level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. Casting a spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.
For example, if you are a 3rd-level cleric with a Wisdom of 16, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd-level, in any combination.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells:
entries: You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of cleric spells requires time: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your cleric spells. Use your Wisdom modifier to determine the saving throw DC or attack modifier for a cleric spell you cast.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast a cleric spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You use a {@item holy symbol|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your cleric spells.

entries.name: Divine Versatility
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can spend one point of divine favor to replace one of your known cleric cantrips with another cantrip from the cleric spell list.

classFeature.name: Faith
entries: You have a number of faith points, as shown in the {@i Faith Points} column of the Class Features (Cleric) table. You can spend faith to channel power from your deity and ask for aid—and you may learn other applications from your Divine Domain.
You recover all expended faith points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: You gain two divine powers from your Divine Domain. Some domains may grant you additional effects as you advance in levels, as noted in the domain description.

entries.name: Saving Throws:
entries: Some Channel Divinity effects require saving throws. When you use such an effect from this class, the DC equals your cleric spell save DC.

classFeature.name: Divine Domain Feature
entries: At 2nd level, you gain a feature from your Divine Domain.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Benedictions
entries: You are able to empower your Channel Divinity powers with {@i Benedictions}. Choose one benediction from your Divine Domain. Whenever you finish a long rest, you may change your selected benediction.

classFeature.name: Divine Domain Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature from your Divine Domain.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Divine Domain Feature
entries: At 8th level, you gain a feature from your Divine Domain.

classFeature.name: Divine Intervention
entries: You spend an action to call upon your deity for aid. Describe the assistance you seek, roll a {@dice d20}, and check the result on the {@i Divine Intervention} table. The GM chooses the nature of the intervention; the effect of any cleric spell or cleric domain spell (such as those included in the {@i Divine Effects} table below) would be appropriate.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Empowered Request:
entries: You can spend any number of faith points and divine favor to increase your chance of success—to a maximum equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1). Add +1 to your result for each point you spend. You must decide how many points you wish to spend before you make your roll.

entries.caption: Divine Intervention
rows: Your deity is greatly offended. You have transgressed. In addition, you can't use this feature again until you finish {@dice 2d4} long rests.
You sense that your deity is displeased. You can't use this feature again until you finish {@dice 1d4} long rests.
There is no response from your deity.
Your deity intervenes—though not necessarily in the way you had hoped.

classFeature.name: Druidic
entries: You know Druidic, the secret language of druids. You can speak the language and use it to leave hidden messages.

You and others who know this language automatically spot such a message. Others can spot the message's presence with a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check—but they can't decipher it without magic.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: Drawing on the divine essence of nature itself, you can cast spells to shape that essence to your will.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st-level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the druid spell list. You learn additional druid cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the {@i Cantrips Known} column of the Class Features (Druid) table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Class Features (Druid) table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st-level and higher. To cast one of your spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Preparing Spells
entries: You prepare the list of druid spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the druid spell list.

entries.name: Preparing Your Spell List:
entries: Choose a number of druid spells equal to your Wisdom modifier + your druid level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. Casting a spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells:
entries: You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of druid spells requires time: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your druid spells. Use your Wisdom modifier to determine the saving throw DC or attack modifier for a druid spell you cast.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast a druid spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item druidic focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your druid spells.

entries.name: Natural Versatility
entries: When you finish a long rest, you may choose one of your druid cantrips and replace it with another cantrip from the druid spell list.

classFeature.name: Primal Power
entries: You have an amount of primal power, as shown in the {@i Primal Power} column of the Class Features (Druid) table. You can spend primal power to shapeshift into animal forms—and you may learn other applications from your Druid Circle.
You recover all expended primal power when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Wild Shape
entries: You are able to spend primal power to magically shapeshift into the form of a beast. See the {@variantrule Wild Shape|GCC} section for more details about this feature.

classFeature.name: Druid Circle
entries: You are a druid, a guardian of the wild world. With primal power, you defend flora and fauna against those who would supplant them with metal and machines.

But where do you draw your primal power from? Do you call on the land to fuel your spells? Do you draw power from beasts and take on powerful animal forms? Or do you call on the natural elements to defend and destroy?
Choose a {@i Druid Circle} to help grow a deep, druidic connection to the natural world. You gain features from your Druid Circle at 1st, 3rd, 6th, and 10th-level.

classFeature.name: Natural Recovery
entries: When you finish a short rest, you can recover some expended spell slots. The spell slots must have a combined level equal to or less than half your druid level (rounded up), and none of the slots can be 6th-level or higher.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Druid Circle Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your Druid Circle.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Druid Circle Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature from your Druid Circle.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Weald Walker
entries: You are able to tap into the primal power of nature and travel great distances. Create a weald tree and you'll never be far from home.

entries.name: Creating a Weald Tree
entries: You may perform a 1 hour wealding ritual to create a weald tree. You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Create Weald Tree

items: {@b Casting Time:} 1 hour
{@b Range:} 10 ft
{@b Components:} V, S

entries: Spend 6 primal power and choose a living, inanimate, nonmagical, Large (or larger) tree within 10 ft. That tree becomes a weald tree.

items: {@b Magical:} Once a tree becomes a weald tree, it is considered magical and can be detected by magical senses (such as the {@spell Detect Magic} spell).
{@b Primal Connections:} You can maintain a number of active weald trees equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 2). If you are already at your maximum number, you can't cast this ritual.

entries.name: Weald Walking
entries: You can spend an action to create a magical link between your weald trees. You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Weald Walk

items: {@b Casting Time:} 1 action
{@b Range:} 10 ft
{@b Components:} V, S
{@b Duration:} 1 round

entries: Choose one weald tree within range and another weald tree on the same plane of existence. For the duration, any creature can step into the target tree and exit from the destination tree by using 5 ft of movement.

items: {@b Homegrown:} You can target only weald trees that you have created yourself.
{@b Creature Size:} A creature must be of a size category equal to or smaller than both the targeted weald trees.

entries: {@b No Metal:} You can't transport metal by weald walking. When a creature passes through a weald tree, any metal objects that they carry are dropped at the foot of the target tree. If this is not possible—or it would cause harm to the creature—the creature can't travel through the weald tree.
Metal that is concealed within a magical container—such as a {@item Bag of Holding} or {@item Heward's Handy Haversack||Handy Haversack} can pass through without detection.

entries.name: Unwealding
entries: You are able to turn a weald tree back into a normal tree by one of two methods:

items: {@b Unwealding Ritual:} You can perform an unwealding ritual to remove the primal power from one of your weald trees. This ritual takes 1 minute, and you must be within 10 ft of the weald tree to cast it.
{@b Destruction:} If a weald tree is killed or otherwise destroyed, it loses its primal power.
{@b Death:} If you die, your weald trees lose their primal power.

classFeature.name: Druid Circle Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature from your Druid Circle.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: Choose one of the following Fighting Styles. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

entries.name: Changing Your Fighting Style:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can choose one of the fighting styles you know and replace it with a different fighting style.

entries.name: Archery
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged weapons.

entries.name: Defense
entries: While you are wearing armor, you gain a +1 bonus to AC.

entries.name: Dueling
entries: When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.

entries.name: Great Weapon Fighting
entries: When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for an attack you make with a melee weapon that you are wielding with two hands, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2.
The weapon must have the two-handed or versatile property for you to gain this benefit.

entries.name: Protection
entries: When a creature you can see attacks a target other than you that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll. You must be wielding a shield.

entries.name: Two-Weapon Fighting
entries: When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier.

entries.name: Thrown Weapon Fighting
entries: You can draw a weapon that has the thrown property as part of the attack you make with the weapon.
In addition, when you hit with a ranged attack using a thrown weapon, you gain a +1 bonus to the damage roll.

entries.name: Unarmed Fighting
entries: Your unarmed strikes deal bludgeoning damage equal to {@damage 1d6} + your Strength modifier. If you have two free hands, the damage increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 1d8}.

When you successfully start a grapple, you can deal {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning damage to the grappled creature. Until the grapple ends, you deal an extra {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning damage to the grappled creature when you hit it with a melee attack.

classFeature.name: Second Wind
entries: If you are at 50% hit points or lower, you can spend a bonus action to regain hit points equal to {@dice 1d10} + your fighter level. The amount of hit points increases as you gain fighter levels, as shown in the {@i Second Wind} column of the Class Features (Fighter) table.
You can use this feature twice. You regain any expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Resolve
entries: You have a number of resolve points, as shown in the {@i Resolve Points} column of the Class Features (Fighter) table. You can spend resolve to overcome danger with fighting maneuvers—and you may learn other applications from your Martial Archetype.
You recover all expended resolve points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Maneuvers
entries: You master two maneuvers of your choice from your list of maneuver options. Once per turn, you may spend a resolve point to use one of your mastered maneuvers.

entries.name: Mastering New Maneuvers:
entries: You master additional maneuvers as you gain more fighter levels, as show in the {@i Maneuvers Known} column of the Class Features (Fighter) table.

entries.name: Replacing a Mastered Maneuver:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you may replace one of your mastered maneuvers with a different one.

entries.name: Saving Throws:
entries: Some of your maneuvers require your target to make a saving throw. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

entries.name: Disarm
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can attempt to disarm it. If the creature is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature drops one item of your choice that it's holding. The object lands at the target's feet.

entries.name: Greater Disarm
entries: (5th-level) You can use this maneuver against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Disarm
entries: (9th-level) You can use this maneuver against Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Intercept
entries: When an adjacent creature is hit by a weapon attack and you are not incapacitated, you can spend your reaction to direct the attack onto yourself. If the attack hits you, reduce the damage you take by {@dice 1d6}.

entries.name: Greater Intercept
entries: (5th-level) Reduce the damage you take by {@dice 1d8}.

entries.name: Superior Intercept
entries: (9th-level) Reduce the damage you take by {@dice 1d10}.

entries.name: Push
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can attempt to push it away from you. If the target is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you knock the target back up to 10 ft.

entries.name: Greater Push
entries: (5th-level) You can use this maneuver against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Push
entries: (9th-level) You can use this maneuver against Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Slam
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can use a bonus action to attempt to knock the creature down. If the target is Large or smaller, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you knock the target {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Greater Slam
entries: (5th-level) You can use this maneuver against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Slam
entries: (9th-level) You can use this maneuver against Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Stagger
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can momentarily stagger it. Until the start of your next turn, the next attack roll made against the creature by an attacker other than you has advantage.

entries.name: Greater Stagger
entries: (5th-level) The creature grants advantage to the next two attack rolls made against it before the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Superior Stagger
entries: (9th-level) The creature grants advantage to the next three attack rolls made against it before the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Taunt
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can attempt to taunt the creature into attacking you. If the target is Large or smaller, it must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature has disadvantage on all attack rolls against targets other than you until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Greater Taunt
entries: (5th-level) You can use this maneuver against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Taunt
entries: (9th-level) You can use this maneuver against Gargantuan creatures.

classFeature.name: Martial Archetype
entries: No two fighters are the same—your personal tastes define your fighting style. Swords, bows, or fists? Aggressive or defensive? Elegant and refined, or harsh and brutal? Long range or up-close and personal?
Choose a {@i Martial Archetype} to help perfect your own, unique style on the battlefield. You gain features from your Martial Archetype at 1st, 3rd, 7th, and 10th-level.

entries.name: Martial Maneuvers
entries: You gain access to four unique maneuvers from your Martial Archetype. Add these to your list of maneuver options.

classFeature.name: Action Surge
entries: Once during your turn, you can take one additional action on top of your regular action and bonus action.
You can use this feature a limited number of times, as shown in the {@i Action Surges} column of the Class Features (Fighter) table. You regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Martial Archetype Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your Martial Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Greater Maneuvers
entries: Your maneuvers are now more effective.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 6th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Martial Archetype Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature from your Martial Archetype.

classFeature.name: Superior Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Indomitable
entries: You can reroll a saving throw that you fail. If you do so, you must use the new roll. You can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest or you choose to spend 1 point of resolve.

classFeature.name: Superior Maneuvers
entries: Your maneuvers are now more effective.

classFeature.name: Fighting Focus
entries: As a bonus action, you can enter a fighting focus. For the next minute, you can attack three times—instead of once—the first time you take the Attack action on your turn. Your fighting focus ends early if you are knocked unconscious or you choose to end it as a free action.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Martial Archetype Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature from your Martial Archetype.

classFeature.name: Martial Arts
entries: Your training in the martial arts gives you mastery of unarmed strikes and monk weapons. You gain the following benefits while you are (a) unarmed or wielding only monk weapons and (b) you aren't wearing armor or wielding a shield:

items: {@b Scorpion Sting:} You can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes and monk weapons.

{@b Dragon's Claw:} You can roll {@damage 1d4} in place of the normal damage of your unarmed strike or monk weapon. This die changes as you gain levels, as shown in the {@i Dragon's Claw} column of the Class Features (Monk) table.

{@b Tiger Swipe:} When you (a) use the Attack action with an unarmed strike or a monk weapon or (b) spend any number of ki points as part of your action, you can make one unarmed strike as a bonus action.

entries.name: Monk Weapons
entries: You can choose a number of weapons to be your monk weapons equal to 5 + your Wisdom modifier (minimum of five weapons). The chosen weapons must each meet the following criteria:

items: The weapon must be a simple or martial weapon.
You must be proficient with the weapon.
The weapon must lack these properties: heavy, special, or two-handed.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: While you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your armor class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Armor Class (AC)
entries.text: 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier

classFeature.name: Ki
entries: You have a number of ki points as shown in the {@i Ki Points} column of the Class Features (Monk) table. You can spend ki to overcome danger with mantras—and you may learn other applications from your Monastic Tradition.
You recover all expended ki points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Flurry of Blows
entries: Immediately after you take the Attack action on your turn, you can spend 1 ki point to make two unarmed strikes as a bonus action.

classFeature.name: Mantras
entries: You master three mantras of your choice from your list of mantra options. To use a mastered mantra, you must spend one ki point.

entries.name: Mastering New Mantras:
entries: You master additional mantras as you gain monk levels, as show in the {@i Mantras Mastered} column of the Class Features (Monk) table.

entries.name: Replacing a Mantra:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you may choose one of your mastered mantras and replace it with a different option.

entries.name: Saving Throws:
entries: Some of your mantras require your target to make a saving throw. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

entries.name: Crashing Thunder
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a Large or smaller creature with a melee weapon attack, you can attempt to push the creature away from you. The creature must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you push the creature back up to 10 ft.

entries.name: Greater Crashing Thunder:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this mantra on Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Crashing Thunder:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this mantra on Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Fell the Forest
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a Large or smaller creature with a weapon attack, you can spend a bonus action to attempt to knock the creature down. The creature must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you knock the creature {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Greater Fell the Forest:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this mantra on Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Fell the Forest:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this mantra on Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Hawk Slash
entries: When you would miss with an attack roll against a creature, you can roll {@dice 1d6} and add it to your attack roll.

entries.name: Greater Hawk Slash:
entries: (5th-level) You can roll {@dice 1d8} and add it to your attack roll.

entries.name: Superior Hawk Slash:
entries: (9th-level) You can roll {@dice 1d10} and add it to your attack roll.

entries.name: Leaping Dragon
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can leap up to 10 ft in a direction of your choice. This movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks from the creature you hit. You must have enough speed to leap this distance.

entries.name: Greater Leaping Dragon:
entries: (5th-level) The distance you can leap increases from 10 ft to 15 ft.

entries.name: Superior Leaping Dragon:
entries: (9th-level) The distance you can leap increases from 15 ft to 20 ft.

entries.name: Move the Mountain
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a Large or smaller creature with a melee weapon attack, you can attempt to move the creature. The creature must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, you can move the target up to 5 ft in a direction of your choice. In addition, you may move up to 5 ft in a direction of your choice. Neither movement triggers an attack of opportunity.

entries.name: Greater Move the Mountain:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this mantra on Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Move the Mountain:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this mantra on Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Tempest Spear
entries: During your turn, you can extend the reach of one unarmed attack you make before the end of your turn. The reach is increased by +5 ft.

entries.name: Greater Tempest Spear:
entries: (5th-level) You can extend the reach of two unarmed attacks you make before the end of your turn.

entries.name: Superior Tempest Spear:
entries: (9th-level) You can extend the reach of three unarmed attacks you make before the end of your turn.

classFeature.name: Monastic Tradition
entries: You are a monk, a master of martial combat and spiritual ki. You can channel the mystical energy that flows through your body—but how do you wield it?

Do you leap into the heart of battle, a blur of fists and fury? Do you bend the elements of nature to your will, striking at your enemies with fire, water, earth, and air? Or do you move silently through shadows, waiting for your enemies to make a lethal mistake?
Choose a {@i Monastic Tradition} to help harness your mystical ki as you master inner peace. You gain features from your Monastic Tradition at 1st, 3rd, 6th, and 10th-level.

entries.name: Monastic Mantras
entries: You gain access to four unique mantras from your Monastic Tradition. Add these to your list of mantra options.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Movement
entries: Your speed increases by 10 feet while you are both (a) not wearing armor and (b) not wielding a shield. This bonus increases when you reach certain monk levels, as shown in the Class Features (Monk) table.
In addition, while you are not wearing armor and not wielding a shield, you can use the {@i Patient Turtle} and {@i Step of the Wind} abilities.

entries.name: Patient Turtle
entries: You can spend one ki point to take the {@action Dodge} action as a bonus action.

entries.name: Step of the Wind
entries: You can spend one ki point to take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Dash} action as a bonus action. In addition, your jump distance is doubled until the end of your turn.

classFeature.name: Deflect Missiles
entries: When you are hit by a ranged weapon attack, you can spend your reaction to deflect the missile. When you do so, the damage you take from the attack is reduced by 1d10 + your Dexterity modifier + your monk level.

entries.name: Catching Butterflies:
entries: If you reduce the damage to 0 when deflecting a missile, you can catch it. The missile must be small enough for you to hold in one hand and you must have at least one hand free.

entries.name: Spitting Wasp:
entries: When you catch a missile in this way, you can spend 1 ki point to (as part of the same reaction) make a ranged attack with the weapon or piece of ammunition you just caught.
You make this attack with proficiency, regardless of your weapon proficiencies. For the attack, the missile counts as a monk weapon with a normal range of 20 feet and a long range of 60 feet.

classFeature.name: Monastic Tradition Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your Monastic Tradition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Slow Fall
entries: When you fall, you can spend your reaction to reduce any falling damage you take by an amount equal to five times your monk level.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Meditation
entries: When you finish a short rest, you can meditate to regain {@dice 1d6} expended ki points. You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Greater Mantras
entries: Your mantras are now more effective.

classFeature.name: Ki-Empowered Strikes
entries: Your unarmed strikes count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

classFeature.name: Monastic Tradition Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature from your Monastic Tradition.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

classFeature.name: Inner Peace
entries: You can spend an action to end one effect on yourself that is causing you to be {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Sky Walk
entries: While you are (a) not wearing armor and (b) not wielding a shield, you can move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during the move.

classFeature.name: Superior Mantras
entries: Your mantras have reached their full potential.

classFeature.name: Lightning Flurry
entries: During your turn, you can flare your ki to activate a burst of focused power. For the next minute, you can use your Flurry of Blows feature without needing to spend a ki point. Your lightning flurry ends early if you are knocked unconscious or you choose to end it as a free action.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Greater Inner Peace
entries: Starting at 10th-level, you are immune to disease and poison.

classFeature.name: Monastic Tradition Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature from your Monastic Tradition.

classFeature.name: Sacred Oath
entries: Words have real power, and the paladin understands this better than anyone. By swearing a sacred oath, you are able to channel your conviction into strength. But what kind of oath have you made? Do you seek to protect the weak and heal the sick? Do you judge the guilty and punish the wicked? Or do you destroy your enemies without mercy and salt their land?
Choose a {@i Sacred Oath} to describe the change you want to create in the world. You gain features from your Sacred Oath at 1st, 3rd, 7th, and 9th-level.

entries.name: Tenets
entries: Each oath has a set of three guiding principles—its {@i tenets}—that help to direct you in the service of your oath. These are sacred vows that you have sworn. Honor these tenets to gain—and maintain—your conviction.

entries.name: Sacred Favor:
entries: If you make a notable effort to honor a tenet, you may be blessed with {@i sacred favor}. You can hold a maximum number of sacred favors at one time equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum 1).
On your turn, as a free action, you may spend one sacred favor to do one of the following:

items: {@b Gain Stamina:} Regain 1 expended hit die.
{@b Gain Power:} Regain 1 expended 1st-level spell slot.
{@b Twist Fate:} Reroll 1 ability check, attack roll, or saving throw. You must accept the second result.
{@b Cause Pain:} Reroll all damage dice of an attack you have just made. You may accept either result.
{@b Forgiveness:} Forgive one transgression you have made.

entries.name: Transgression:
entries: If you break or reject one of the tenets of your oath, some of your sacred power may be stripped away for a time.
Roll a {@dice d6} and check the {@i Transgression} table below to find out which class feature you lose access to. Reroll any result that doesn't fully apply to you.

entries.name: Penance:
entries: If you have transgressed, you will have to perform a penance to regain your conviction. The scale of this penance may vary depending on the severity of your transgression, but some common forms include:

items: {@b Donate:} You make a charitable donation of goods, coin, or time to a worthy cause.
{@b Confess:} You confess your transgression to a higher-ranking agent of your oath and are forgiven.
{@b Contemplate:} You spend a period of time in dedicated contemplation of your oath.
{@b Quest:} You complete a sacred quest in the service of your oath.
{@b Sacrifice:} You give up something of significant personal value.

entries: If your penance is accepted, you regain one lost feature.

entries.name: Lay on Hands
entries: You are able to share the power of your conviction through a simple touch. You gain access to one {@i Lay on Hands} ability from your oath.

entries.name: Oath Smite
entries: You gain access to one unique smite from your Sacred Oath. Add this to your list of smite options.

entries.name: Oath Spells
entries: Each oath has a list of spells—its oath spells—that you gain at the paladin levels noted in the oath description. Once you gain an oath spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day.
If you have an oath spell that doesn't appear on the paladin spell list, the spell is nonetheless a paladin spell for you.

entries.name: Oath Aura
entries: Starting at 6th-level, you gain access to one unique aura from your Sacred Oath. Add this to your list of aura options.

classFeature.name: Conviction
entries: Your conviction in your oath gives you strength. You have a number of conviction points, as shown in the {@i Conviction Points} column of the Class Features (Paladin) table. You can spend conviction to smite your enemies—and you may learn other applications from your Sacred Oath.
You recover all expended conviction points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Smite
entries: You master two smites of your choice from your list of smite options. Once per turn, when you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you may spend one or more conviction points to use one of your mastered smites.

entries.name: Mastering New Smites:
entries: You master additional smites as you gain more paladin levels, as show in the {@i Smites Mastered} column of the Class Features (Paladin) table.

entries.name: Replacing a Mastered Smite:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you may replace one of your mastered smites with a different one.

entries.name: Saving Throws:
entries: Some of your smites require your target to make a saving throw. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

entries.name: Branding
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can spend two conviction points to deal an additional {@damage 1d8} radiant damage. In addition, until the smite ends, the creature sheds dim light in a 5 ft radius and can't benefit from the {@condition Invisible} condition.

entries.name: Smite Duration:
entries: Concentration, up to 1 minute.

entries.name: Greater Branding:
entries: (5th-level, +1 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 2d8}.

entries.name: Superior Branding:
entries: (9th-level, +3 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 3d8}.

entries.name: Blinding
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can spend two conviction points to deal an additional {@damage 1d8} radiant damage. In addition, the creature must make a Constitution saving throw. If it fails, the creature is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Greater Blinding:
entries: (5th-level, +1 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 2d8}.

entries.name: Superior Blinding:
entries: (9th-level, +3 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 3d8}.

entries.name: Divine
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can spend two conviction points to deal an additional {@damage 1d8} radiant damage. If the creature is undead or a fiend, the damage increases by {@damage 1d8}.

entries.name: Greater Divine:
entries: (5th-level, +1 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 2d8}.

entries.name: Superior Divine:
entries: (9th-level, +3 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 3d8}.

entries.name: Searing
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can spend two conviction points to deal an additional {@damage 1d8} fire damage. In addition, the creature ignites in flame.

At the start of each of its turns until the smite ends, the target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes {@damage 1d8} fire damage. On a successful save, the smite ends. If the creature—or another creature within 5 feet of it—uses an action to put out the flames (or if some other effect douses the flames), the smite ends.

entries.name: Smite Duration:
entries: Concentration, up to 1 minute.

entries.name: Greater Searing:
entries: (5th-level, +1 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 2d8} and the ongoing damage increases to {@damage 1d10}.

entries.name: Superior Searing:
entries: (9th-level, +3 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 3d8} and the ongoing damage increases to {@damage 1d12}.

entries.name: Thunderous
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can spend two conviction points to deal an additional {@damage 1d8} thunder damage. The creature must make a Strength saving throw or be pushed back 10 ft and knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Greater Thunderous:
entries: (5th-level, +1 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 2d8} and the creature is pushed back up to 15 ft.

entries.name: Superior Thunderous:
entries: (9th-level, +3 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 3d8} and the creature is pushed back up to 20 ft.

entries.name: Wrathful
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can spend two conviction points to deal an additional {@damage 1d8} psychic damage. In addition, the creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. If it fails, the creature is {@condition fightened} of you until the effect ends.
As an action, the creature can make a Wisdom check against your smite save DC to end this effect.

entries.name: Smite Duration:
entries: Concentration, up to 1 minute.

entries.name: Greater Wrathful:
entries: (5th-level, +1 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 2d8}.

entries.name: Superior Wrathful:
entries: (9th-level, +3 conviction) The base damage increases to {@damage 3d8}.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: Choose one of the following Fighting Styles. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

entries.name: Changing Your Fighting Style:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can choose one of the fighting styles you know and replace it with a different fighting style.

entries.name: Defense
entries: While you are wearing armor, you gain a +1 bonus to AC.

entries.name: Dueling
entries: When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.

entries.name: Great Weapon Fighting
entries: When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for an attack you make with a melee weapon that you are wielding with two hands, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2.
The weapon must have the two-handed or versatile property for you to gain this benefit.

entries.name: Protection
entries: When a creature you can see attacks a target other than you that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll. You must be wielding a shield.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You gain the ability to cast paladin spells by channeling your conviction.

entries.name: Preparing Spells
entries: You prepare the list of paladin spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the paladin spell list.

entries.name: Preparing Your Spell List:
entries: Choose a number of paladin spells equal to your Charisma modifier + your paladin level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level lower than or equal to your {@i Maximum Spell Level}. Casting a spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells:
entries: You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of paladin spells requires time: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Casting Spells
entries: To cast a paladin spell of 1st-level or higher, you must spend a number of conviction points as shown in the {@i Paladin Spellcasting} table below. You recover all expended conviction points when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Upcasting Spells:
entries: When you cast a paladin spell at a higher spell level, you can't exceed your Maximum Spell Level—even if you have enough conviction points.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your paladin spells. Use your Charisma modifier to determine the saving throw DC or attack modifier for a paladin spell you cast.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item holy symbol|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your paladin spells.

classFeature.name: Divine Health
entries: You are immune to disease.

classFeature.name: Sacred Oath Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your Sacred Oath.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Sacred Aura
entries: You master one sacred aura of your choice. You can spend a bonus action to radiate your sacred aura lasting for up to 10 minutes (or until you are rendered unconcious).
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1), and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Replacing a Sacred Aura:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you may choose one of your sacred auras and replace it with a different option.

entries.name: Unique Effect:
entries: A creature can't benefit from the same sacred aura from multiple sources.

entries.name: Aura of Courage
entries: You and friendly creatures within 10 feet of you can't be {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Aura of Protection
entries: Whenever you or a friendly creature within 10 feet of you must make a saving throw, the creature gains a bonus to the saving throw equal to your Charisma modifier (with a minimum bonus of +1).

entries.name: Aura of Radiance
entries: You and friendly creatures within 10 feet of you gain resistance to necrotic damage. In addition, your melee weapon attacks deal +1 radiant damage.

entries.name: Aura of Wrath
entries: You and friendly creatures within 10 feet of you gain a +1 damage bonus when making weapon attacks.

classFeature.name: Sacred Oath Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature from your Sacred Oath.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Sacred Oath Feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature from your Sacred Oath.

classFeature.name: Voice of the Crusader
entries: With conviction, you are able to instill the tenets of your oath in even the most dangerous of enemies. As an action, you may choose one of your oath's tenets and proclaim it. Up to twelve creatures of your choice that you can see within 60 ft must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is inspired—or bound—by your tenet for up to 1 hour.
A creature affected in this way is compelled to honor the spirit of the tenet you have proclaimed. The creature retains its own will and may choose how it achieves this.

entries.name: Immunities:
entries: Creatures must be able to hear and understand you. Creatures that can't be charmed are immune to this effect.

entries.name: Conviction:
entries: You may spend a number of conviction points as you proclaim your tenet. For every point of conviction, you may influence 1 additional person.

classFeature.name: Greater Sacred Aura
entries: At 10th-level, choose one additional sacred aura. Your aura now radiates both effects at the same time.

classFeature.name: Survival Instincts
entries: You gain two survival instincts of your choice. When you gain certain ranger levels, you gain additional survival instincts of your choice—as shown in the {@i Survival Instincts} column of the Class Features (Ranger) table.

entries.name: Replacing Instincts:
entries: When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the instincts you have and replace it with another instinct that you could learn at that level.
As a ranger, you able to hone the following survival instincts. You can't choose the same instinct multiple times unless that instinct specifies otherwise.

entries.name: A Forest Friend
entries: You gain the trust of a tiny animal friend. You both share a basic, wordless understanding of each other—though the animal is still subject to its natural instincts. Your animal must be a tiny CR 0 beast, and—when relevant—it shares your pool of actions.

If your animal friend is reduced to 0 hit points, you can spend one hit die or suffer a level of exhaustion to reduce it to 1 hit point instead. If your animal friend leaves or dies, you can spend time during a long rest to bond with another creature from the surrounding environment.

entries.name: Many Friends:
entries: You may take this instinct multiple times, gaining an additional animal friend each time.

entries.name: A Light in the Dark
entries: You know how to craft well-made candles and torches using natural materials. When you attempt to craft basic lighting equipment, you roll with advantage. In addition, your crafted lights burn for twice as long as normal.

entries.name: Scrap Lights:
entries: You can spend 1 action and 1 scrap to make an improvised torch that lasts for up to 1 hour.

entries.name: Always Prepared
entries: You like to have at least one trap prepared. When you finish a long rest, you may prepare one trap worth up to 2 scrap without needing to spend your own scrap.

entries.name: Greater Preparation:
entries: Starting at 5th-level, your trap can be worth up to 3 scrap.

entries.name: Superior Preparation:
entries: Starting at 9th-level, your trap can be worth up to 4 scrap.

entries.name: Expert Tracker
entries: You know how to study tracks left behind by a creature. When you study a set of tracks, you roll with advantage and—if successful—gain an answer to one of the following questions (your choice):

items: How many creatures made these tracks?
What type of creature made these tracks?
How old are these tracks?
Where are these tracks heading?

entries: If you critically succeed on your tracking, you gain answers to two questions of your choice instead of one.

entries.name: Favored Enemy
entries: Choose one common or three uncommon favored enemies. When you mark a favored enemy as your quarry, your quarry damage increases from {@damage 1d4} to {@damage 1d6}.

entries.name: Greater Favored Enemy:
entries: Starting at 5th-level, the additional damage you deal increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 1d8}.

entries.name: Superior Favored Enemy:
entries: Starting at 9th-level, the additional damage you deal increases from {@damage 1d8} to {@damage 1d10}.

entries.name: Many Enemies:
entries: You may take this instinct multiple times, selecting new enemies each time.

rows: Beasts, Fey, Humanoids (choose two races), Monstrosities, Undead
Aberrations, Celestials, Constructs, Dragons, Elementals, Fiends, Giants, Oozes, Plants

entries.name: Focused Hunter
entries: You can use your {@i Hunter's Focus} feature one additional time, regaining expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Extreme Focus:
entries: You may take this instinct multiple times, gaining an additional +1 use each time.

entries.name: I Can Sleep Anywhere
entries: You know how camp comfortably in the wild. When trying to locate a good site for camp, or when setting up camp equipment—tents, campfires, etc—you roll with advantage.

entries.name: Scrap Fire:
entries: You can spend 1 action and 1 scrap to light a basic campfire that lasts for up to 1 hours.

entries.name: Scrap Tent:
entries: You can spend 10 minutes and 6 scrap to make an improvised tent that lasts for up to 8 hours.

entries.name: Light Sleeper
entries: While you are asleep, you remain half-aware of what's happening around you. You can sense movement and may make Wisdom (Perception) checks while you sleep—though you have disadvantage.

entries.name: Natural Sense of Direction
entries: When travelling outside, you may navigate as if you had a map and compass. In addition, difficult terrain doesn't slow you or your group's travel during long journeys.

entries.name: Scrap Compass:
entries: You can spend 1 action and 1 scrap to make an improvised compass that lasts for up to 1 hour.

entries.name: Ranger's Expertise
entries: Choose one skill: Animal Handling, Athletics, History, Insight, Investigation, Medicine, Nature, Perception, Stealth, or Survival.
You gain proficiency in this skill if you don't already have it, and you can add double your proficiency bonus to ability checks using it.

entries.name: Scavenger
entries: Once per long rest, you may scavenge a location for suitable scrap material. You regain {@dice 1d4} expended scrap from your location.

entries.name: Greater Scavenger:
entries: Starting at 5th-level, the amount of scrap you recover increases from {@dice 1d4} to {@dice 1d6}.

entries.name: Superior Scavenger:
entries: Starting at 9th-level, the amount of scrap you recover increases from {@dice 1d6} to {@dice 1d8}.

entries.name: Shortcut to Mushrooms
entries: When you forage, you find twice as much food or water as you normally would.

entries.name: Walk a Mile in my Shoes
entries: Your base walking speed increases by 5 ft. In addition, you gain a climbing and swimming speed equal to your base walking speed.

classFeature.name: Hunter's Focus
entries: You can spend a bonus action to enter a hunter's focus that lasts for up to 10 minutes. While you are focused, you gain the following benefits:

items: {@b Quarry:} As a free action, you can mark one creature that you can see as your quarry. Once per turn, when you hit your quarry with a weapon attack, you may deal an extra {@damage 1d4} damage. If your quarry is reduced to 0 hit points, you can spend a bonus action to mark a different creature as your quarry.
{@b Tracker:} You have advantage on any Wisdom (Perception) and Wisdom (Survival) checks you make to track, spot, or locate any creatures.
{@b Alert:} You can't be surprised.

entries: Your focus ends early if you are reduced to 0 hit points or otherwise rendered unconscious.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Greater Hunter's Focus:
entries: Starting at 5th-level, the additional damage you deal increases from {@damage 1d4} to {@damage 1d6}.

entries.name: Superior Hunter's Focus:
entries: Starting at 9th-level, the additional damage you deal increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 1d8}.

classFeature.name: Scrap
entries: You have an amount of salvaged scrap, as shown in the {@i Scrap Points} column of the Class Features (Ranger) table. You can spend scrap to create traps—and you may learn other ways to use scrap from your Survival Instincts and your Ranger Archetype.
You recover all expended scrap points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Traps
entries: You are able to construct ranger traps that can bait, capture, and control your prey.

entries.name: Preparing Your Traps:
