entries: When you finish a short or long rest, you can spend any amount of your remaining scrap to prepare a number of traps of your choice.
At any one time, you can have a maximum number of prepared traps equal to your Wisdom modifier. Prepared traps that have not been activated by the time you finish a long rest expire automatically.

entries.name: Activating a Trap:
entries: Once per turn, you may activate one of your prepared traps if it's condition has been met. When you activate a trap, it is expended. Some traps may require your target to make a saving throw—the DC is calculated as follows:

entries.name: Bait Trap
entries: Spend 1 scrap to prepare a bait trap. When a creature moves adjacent to you or your allies, you can activate a bait trap. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is distracted by your bait and another creature of your choice (that is adjacent to the baited creature) can spend their reaction to move up to 10 ft without provoking an attack of opportunity from it.

items: {@b Extra-Strong:} {@i (+1 scrap)} Up to two creatures of your choice can move away from your baited prey.
{@b Distracting:} {@i (+1 scrap)} The maximum distance increases from 10 ft to 15 ft.
{@b Interrupt:} {@i (+1 scrap)} Instead of moving, your chosen creature can spend their reaction to make a melee attack against the baited creature.

entries.name: Marking Trap
entries: Spend 1 scrap to prepare a marking trap. When a creature moves within 15 ft of your or your allies, you can activate a marking trap. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is marked with brightly-colored dye for up to 1 minute. While marked, the creature can't benefit from the {@condition invisible} condition.

items: {@b Easy Target:} {@i (+1 scrap)} While marked, the creature can't benefit from half or three-quarters cover.
{@b Trail:} {@i (+1 scrap)} The dye leaves a clear trail. While marked, you know exactly where the creature has moved.
{@b Blinding:} {@i (+2 scrap)} On a failed save, the creature is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Pit Trap
entries: Spend 1 scrap to prepare a pit trap. When a creature that you can see ends its turn without moving, you can activate a pit trap. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature falls into a 5 ft by 5 ft pit that is 10 ft deep.
The creature must be on the ground, and the ground must be sufficiently deep and soft/fragile for your pit without causing a bottomless hole.

items: {@b Slippery:} {@i (+1 scrap)} Attempts to climb out of this trap are made with disadvantage.
{@b Spiked:} {@i (+1 scrap)} On a failed save, spikes at the bottom of the pit deal {@damage 2d4} piercing damage.
{@b Scaled:} {@i (+1 scrap)} You can increase the diameter of your pit by 5 ft, or the depth by 5 ft.

entries.name: Rockslide Trap
entries: Spend 1 scrap to prepare a rockslide trap. When a creature that you can see moves adjacent to a wall of equal or greater height, you can activate a rockslide trap. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is knocked prone.

items: {@b Bludgeoning:} {@i (+1 scrap)} On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d4} bludgeoning damage.
{@b Dusty:} {@i (+1 scrap)} On a failed save, the creature is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.
{@b Stunning:} {@i (+3 scrap)} On a failed save, the creature is stunned until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Snare Trap
entries: Spend 1 scrap to prepare a snare trap. When a creature that you can see moves within 15 ft of you or one of your allies, you can activate a snare trap. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is grappled until the end of its next turn.
A grappled creature can attempt to break free early using force—it may spend an action to make an Athletics check against your Trap DC.

items: {@b Durable:} {@i (+1 scrap)} Attempts to break free of this trap are made with disadvantage.
{@b Piercing:} {@i (+1 scrap)} On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d4} piercing damage.
{@b Tenacious:} {@i (+1 scrap)} On a failed save, the creature is grappled for one additional turn.

entries.name: Stench Trap
entries: Spend 1 scrap to prepare a stench trap. When a creature that you can see makes a weapon attack against you or your allies, you can activate a stench trap. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is marked with a disgusting scent until the end of its turn and must make its attack with disadvantage.

items: {@b Sneezing:} {@i (+1 scrap)} On a failed save, after the attack is resolved, the creature drops one item of your choice.
{@b Spores:} {@i (+2 scrap)} On a failed save, the creature is {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn.
{@b Toxic:} {@i (+1 scrap)} On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d4} poison damage.

entries.name: Salvaging Traps
entries: If you activate one of your ranger traps and it doesn't work—or you want to change one of your prepared traps—you can spend 1 minute to salvage it. You recover up to half of the scrap that was used to prepare the trap (rounded up).

classFeature.name: Ranger Archetype
entries: Rangers are skilled trackers, hunters, and trappers. But no two rangers hunt the same—your personal tastes define your hunting style. Are you a lone wolf or a pack leader? Do you favor weapons, spells, or traps? Where do you hunt, and what's your prey?
Choose a {@i Ranger Archetype} to help perfect your own, unique hunting style. You gain features from your Ranger Archetype at 1st, 3rd, 6th, and 9th-level.

entries.name: Specialist Traps
entries: You gain access to one unique trap from your Ranger Archetype. Add this to your list of  trap options.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: Choose one of the following Fighting Styles. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

entries.name: Changing Your Fighting Style:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can choose one of the fighting styles you know and replace it with a different fighting style.

entries.name: Archery
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged weapons.

entries.name: Defense
entries: While you are wearing armor, you gain a +1 bonus to AC.

entries.name: Dueling
entries: When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.

entries.name: Two-Weapon Fighting
entries: When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier.

classFeature.name: Ranger's Prey
entries: Choose one of the following options.

entries.name: Colossus Slayer
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, the creature takes an extra {@damage 1d8} damage if it's below its hit point maximum.

entries.name: Giant Killer
entries: When a Large or larger creature within 5 feet of you hits or misses you with an attack, you can use your reaction to attack that creature immediately after its attack, provided that you can see the creature.

entries.name: Horde Breaker
entries: Once during your turn, when you make a weapon attack, you can make another attack with the same weapon against a different creature that is within 5 feet of the original target and within range of your weapon.

classFeature.name: Ranger Archetype Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your Ranger Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Ranger Archetype Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature from your Ranger Archetype.

classFeature.name: Defensive Tactics
entries: Choose one of the following options.

entries.name: Escape the Horde
entries: Opportunity attacks against you are made with disadvantage.

entries.name: Multiattack Defense
entries: When a creature hits you with an attack, you gain a +4 bonus to AC against all subsequent attacks made by that creature for the rest of the turn.

entries.name: Steel Will
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Ranger Archetype Feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature from your Ranger Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ranger's Strike
entries: Choose one of the following options. You may use your chosen strike a number of times equal to your wisdom modifier, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Volley
entries: You can use your action to make a ranged attack against any number of creatures within 10 feet of a point you can see within your weapon's range. You must have ammunition for each target, and you make a separate attack roll for each target.

entries.name: Whirlwind Attack
entries: You can use your action to make a melee attack against any number of creatures within 5 feet of you, with a separate attack roll for each target.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: Choose either (a) two of your skill proficiencies or (b) one of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with thieves' tools.
Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

classFeature.name: Sneak Attack
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a creature with a finesse or ranged weapon attack, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage to that creature. One of the following must also apply:

items: a. You have advantage on your attack roll.
b. Your target is within 5 ft of a creature hostile to it (not including yourself) that is not incapacitated. In addition, you don't have disadvantage on your attack roll.

entries: The amount of the extra damage you deal increases as you gain rogue levels, as shown in the {@i Sneak Attack} column of the Class Features (Rogue) table.

classFeature.name: Thieves' Cant
entries: You can speak in thieves' cant—a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. Only another creature that knows thieves' cant is able to understand such messages. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.
In addition, you understand a set of secret signs and symbols used to convey short, simple messages.

entries.name: Trusted Crew
entries: You can teach your allies a few basic phrases and symbols of thieves' cant to enable them to understand your own coded dialect and secret messages.

Whenever you finish a long rest, you may choose a number of creatures equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). If you were able to teach these creatures some basic phrases during your rest, they gain the {@i Trusted Crew} status and can understand you whenever you speak, write, or sign in thieves' cant.
Your trusted crew can't speak or understand thieves' cant as a general practice—only the unique dialect spoken by you and the rest of your crew.

entries.name: Change Dialect:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can change your specific dialect of thieves' cant. Any creature that had your {@i Trusted Crew} status now loses it.

entries.name: Greater Trusted Crew:
entries: Starting at 5th-level, creatures that benefit from your {@i Trusted Crew} status can now speak and sign in thieves' cant with you or any other creature that has your {@i Trusted Crew} status.

entries.name: Secret Message
entries: You can spend a bonus action to pass a secret message in thieves' cant to a creature that can see or hear you clearly. Your message can be conveyed vocally or with sign language, and can be up to two words long.

classFeature.name: Focus
entries: You have a number of focus points, as shown in the {@i Focus Points} column of the Class Features (Rogue) table. You can spend focus to outwit your foes with cunning exploits—and you may learn other applications from your Roguish Archetype.
You recover all expended focus points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Exploits
entries: You master two exploits of your choice from your list of exploit options. Once per turn, you may spend a focus point to use one of your mastered exploits.

entries.name: Mastering New Exploits:
entries: You master additional exploits as you gain more rogue levels, as show in the {@i Exploits Known} column of the Class Features (Rogue) table.

entries.name: Replacing a Mastered Exploit:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you may replace one of your mastered exploits with a different one.

entries.name: Saving Throws:
entries: Some of your exploits require your target to make a saving throw. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

entries.name: Blind
entries: When a Larger or smaller creature makes a weapon attack against you, you can spend your reaction to attempt to blind the creature before it makes the attack roll. The creature must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition Blinded} until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Greater Blind:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this exploit against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Blind:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this exploit against Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Distract
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can distract it to expose a weak point. Until the start of your next turn, the next attack roll made against the creature has advantage.

entries.name: Greater Distract:
entries: (5th-level) The creature grants advantage to the next two attack rolls made against it before the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Superior Distract:
entries: (9th-level) The creature grants advantage to the next three attack rolls made against it before the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Parkour
entries: When you make an ability check and use Acrobatics or Stealth, you can roll 1d6 and add it to the result. You can wait until after you roll your check before deciding to use this exploit, but you must decide before the GM says whether your check succeeds or fails.

entries.name: Greater Parkour:
entries: (5th-level) Your bonus increases from 1d6 to 1d8.

entries.name: Superior Parkour:
entries: (9th-level) Your bonus increases from 1d8 to 1d10.

entries.name: Riposte
entries: When a creature misses you with a melee weapon attack, you can spend your reaction to make one weapon attack against that same creature. If your attack hits, you deal 1d6 extra damage.

entries.name: Greater Riposte:
entries: (5th-level) The damage increases from 1d6 to 1d8.

entries.name: Superior Riposte:
entries: (9th-level) The damage increases from 1d8 to 1d10.

entries.name: Slip
entries: When you hit a Large or smaller creature with a melee weapon attack, you can use a bonus action to attempt to make the creature fall over. The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, you knock the target prone.

entries.name: Greater Slip:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this exploit against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Slip:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this exploit against Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Stagger
entries: When you hit a Large or smaller creature with a ranged weapon attack on which you have advantage, you can stagger it. The creature's base speed is reduced by half until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Greater Stagger:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this exploit against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Stagger:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this exploit against Gargantuan creatures.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype
entries: Rogues share many features—quick reflexes, expertise in a wide range of skills, and a deadly precision-based approach to combat. But different rogues steer those talents in different directions. Do you like to steal, stealth, or cheat your marks? Do you fight from the shadows, or dance in the center of battle? Do you favor the weight of a loaded crossbow, or the cold metal of a freshly-sharpened dagger?
Choose a {@i Roguish Archetype} to reflect your own focus and preferred techniques.
You gain features from your Roguish Archetype at 1st, 3rd, 7th, and 9th-level.

entries.name: Roguish Exploits
entries: You gain access to four unique exploits from your Roguish Archetype. Add these to your list of exploit options.

classFeature.name: Cunning Action
entries: You can spend a bonus action to take one of the following actions: {@action Aim|GCC}, {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide}.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can spend your reaction to halve the attack's damage against you.

classFeature.name: Greater Exploits
entries: Your {@i Roguish Exploits} are now more effective.

classFeature.name: Greater Expertise
entries: At 6th-level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with thieves' tools) to gain the benefit of expertise.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 6th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature from your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Superior Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype Feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature from your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Superior Exploits
entries: Your {@i Roguish Exploits} are even more effective.

classFeature.name: Roguish Fortune
entries: If your attack misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20.
You can use this feature up to three times, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Sorcery
entries: You gain the ability to cast sorcerer spells by channeling the raw, sorcerous power that burns within you.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st-level, you know four cantrips of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. You learn additional cantrips of your choice from the sorcerer spell list at higher levels, as shown in the {@i Cantrips Known} column of the Class Features (Sorcerer) table.

entries.name: Replacing Known Cantrips:
entries: When you gain a sorcerer level, you may choose one of the sorcerer cantrips you know and replace it with another cantrip from the sorcerer spell list.

entries.name: Sorcery Points
entries: You have a pool of sorcery points as shown in the {@i Sorcery Points} column of the Class Features (Sorcerer) table. To cast a sorcerer spell of 1st-level or higher, you must spend a number of sorcery points as shown in the {@i Sorcerous Spellcasting} table below.
You recover all expended sorcery points when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-level and Higher
entries: At 1st-level, you know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. You learn additional spells of your choice from the sorcerer spell list at higher levels, as shown in the {@i Spells Known} column of the Class Features (Sorcerer) table. Any spell that you learn must be of a level lower than or equal to your {@i Maximum Spell Level}.

entries.name: Replacing Known Spells:
entries: When you gain a sorcerer level, you may choose one of the sorcerer spells you know and replace it with another spell from the sorcerer spell list. The new spell can be of any level that is lower than or equal to your {@i Maximum Spell Level}.

entries.name: Upcasting Spells:
entries: When casting a sorcerer spell at a higher spell level, you can't exceed your {@i Maximum Spell Level}—even if you have enough sorcery points.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells. Use your Charisma to determine the saving throw DC or attack modifier for a sorcerer spell you cast.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You don't need an arcane focus to cast sorcery—you are your own spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells.

entries.name: Sorcerous Versatility
entries: When you finish a long rest, you may replace one of your known sorcerer spells (including cantrips) with another spell from the sorcerer spell list. The new spell must be of the same spell level as the spell you replace.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: The rules of magic are your plaything as you twist and shape spells into your own sorcerous design.

You master two {@filter metamagics|optionalfeatures|Source=GCC|Feature Type=MM} of your choice. When you cast a spell, you may declare which metamagics (if any) you are applying to it—you can apply only one metamagic to a spell that you are casting, unless otherwise noted.

entries.name: Mastering New Metamagics:
entries: You master additional metamagics as you gain more sorcerer levels, as shown in the {@i Metamagics Known} column of the Class Features (Sorcerer) table.

entries.name: Replacing a Mastered Metamagic:
entries: Each time you gain a sorcerer level, you may replace any or all of your mastered metamagics with a different choice.
In addition, you may use your {@i Sorcerous Versatility} class feature to change one mastered metamagic instead of a known spell selection.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin
entries: Different sorcerers claim different origins for their innate magical power. Some are born with arcane power surging through them, marked from birth as wild fonts of sorcery. Others gain their sorcery through a sudden, life-changing event that forces great power—and great responsibility—upon them.
Whatever your background, this chapter introduces a variety of origins for you to choose from. Define your sorcerous heritage and harness your arcane magic.
Choose a Sorcerous Origin. You gain features from your Sorcerous Origin at 1st, 3rd, 6th, and 10th-level.

entries.name: Origin Spells
entries: Your Sorcerous Origin grants you a unique list of spells—its {@i origin} spells. At 1st, 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th-level, you may choose one spell from that respective tier and add it to your list of known sorcerer spells as an {@i extra} spell.
If you have an origin spell that doesn't normally appear on the sorcerer spell list, that spell is nonetheless a sorcerer spell for you.

entries.name: Permanent Choice:
entries: Once you choose an origin spell, that selection is permanent—you can't change it later using your {@i Sorcerous Versatility}.

entries.name: Origin Metamagics
entries: You gain access to four unique {@filter metamagics|optionalfeatures|Source=GCC|Feature Type=MM} from your Sorcerous Origin. Add these to your list of metamagic options.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Recovery
entries: Your sorcerous body feeds on magic, turning the raw energies of the world into powerful sorcery.
When you take damage from a spell cast by another creature or object, you can spend your reaction to regain a number of expended sorcery points equal to the level of the spell that hurt you.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Greater Sorcerous Recovery:
entries: Starting at 5th-level, you can use this feature twice.

entries.name: Superior Sorcerous Recovery:
entries: Starting at 9th-level, you can use this feature three times.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature from your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature from your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Metamorphosis
entries: You infuse your physical form with sorcery, transforming yourself—temporarily—into a sorcerous avatar of magic.

You gain two {@i metamorphosis forms} as determined by your sorcerous origin. You may spend an action to cast {@i Metamorphosis} and transform into one of these forms—you may choose which form each time you cast the spell.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Innate Power:
entries: As a sorcerer, you can cast Metamorphosis without spending any sorcery points.

entries.name: Interrupts:
entries: As a spell, Metamorphosis can be interrupted by normal means (such as {@spell Counterspell}). In these cases, Metamorphosis counts as a 6th-level spell.

entries.name: Metamorphosis

items: {@b Casting Time:} 1 action
{@b Range:} Self
{@b Components:} V, S
{@b Duration:} Up to 1 minute

entries: You transmute your physical form into raw, sorcerous power. Choose a metamorphosis form as permitted by your sorcerous origin—until the spell ends, you gain all the features of that form.
Your metamorphosis lasts until either (a) 1 minute has passed, (b) you end it as a bonus action, (c) you fall unconscious, or (d) you are shapeshifted into another form by some other effect.

entries.name: Acid
entries: Your flesh transforms into gelatinous, corrosive ooze.

entries.name: Corrosive Blood:
entries: You are immune to acid damage and have vulnerability to slashing damage.

entries.name: Amorphous:
entries: You can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing (items you are carrying might not fit, however).

entries.name: Acid Rain:
entries: You can spend your action to create a 10 ft radius sphere of acid rain centered on yourself. Each creature in that area (excluding yourself) must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d8} acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Bludgeoning
entries: You are surrounded by a powerful, ceaseless wind.

entries.name: Wind Shield:
entries: You gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks.

entries.name: Moon Step:
entries: You gain a flying speed equal to your movement speed. If you are still flying when the spell ends, you fall unless you can somehow prevent it.

entries.name: Gust:
entries: You can spend your action to create a 10 ft radius sphere of swirling wind centered on yourself. Each creature in that area (excluding yourself) must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 2d10} bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If a large or smaller creature fails the save, that creature is pushed up to 10 ft away from the center of the sphere.

entries.name: Cold
entries: Your body is covered with glistening ice crystals.

entries.name: Cold-blooded:
entries: You are immune to cold damage and have vulnerability to fire damage.

entries.name: White Walker:
entries: You can walk across water as if it were solid ground. In addition, you can move across difficult terrain created by ice or snow without spending extra movement.

entries.name: Ice Age:
entries: You can spend your action to create a 15 ft cone of ice extending from you in a direction of your choice. Each creature in range must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d6} cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that fails its save against this effect has its speed halved until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Glowing red veins of searing power cover your body.

entries.name: Hot-blooded:
entries: You are immune to fire damage and have vulnerability to cold damage.

entries.name: Living Torch:
entries: You emit bright light in a 30 ft radius and dim light for an additional 30 ft.

entries.name: Scorched Partizan:
entries: You can spend your action to create a line of fire 15 feet long and 5 feet wide extending from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d8} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Force
entries: Your body glimmers with sparkling, arcane force.

entries.name: Arcane Flesh:
entries: You are immune to force damage and have vulnerability to psychic damage.

entries.name: Unstoppable:
entries: You can move through and occupy a hostile creature's space. If you end your turn in a hostile creature's space, that creature is pushed to the nearest unoccupied space (the creature may choose which space).

entries.name: Force Push:
entries: You can spend your action to create a 10 ft radius sphere of arcane force centered on yourself. Each creature in that area (excluding yourself) must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 2d10} force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If a large or smaller creature fails the save, that creature is pushed up to 10 ft away from you.

entries.name: Lightning
entries: Your body crackles with sparks of arcane lightning.

entries.name: Sparkster:
entries: You are immune to lightning damage and have vulnerability to cold damage.

entries.name: Static Charge:
entries: You can climb and cling to difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

entries.name: Lightning Lance:
entries: You can spend your action to create a line of lightning 15 feet long and 5 feet wide extending from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d8} lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Necrotic
entries: Black, pulsating veins of decay cover your body.

entries.name: Shadowheart:
entries: You are immune to necrotic damage and have vulnerability to radiant damage.

entries.name: Dark Aura:
entries: The area in a 10 ft radius around you is (a) in dim light and (b) is difficult terrain for creatures other than you. The radius moves with you.

entries.name: Decay:
entries: You can spend your action to touch a creature within 5 ft of you. That creature must make a Constitution saving throw. It takes {@damage 2d10} necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that fails its save against this effect is Poisoned until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Piercing
entries: Sharp spikes of earth and rock cover your body.

entries.name: Quill Armor:
entries: You gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks.

entries.name: Stonestepper:
entries: You can move across difficult terrain made of earth or stone without spending extra movement. You can move through solid earth or stone as if it was air and without destabilizing it, but you can't end your movement there. If you do so, you are ejected to the nearest unoccupied space, your metamorphosis ends, and you are stunned until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Obsidian Spear:
entries: You can spend your action to fling piercing spikes in a line 15 feet long and 5 feet wide extending from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d8} piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Poison
entries: You grow pointed fangs, sharp claws, and a poisonous, barbed tail.

entries.name: Toxic Blood:
entries: You are immune to poison damage and have vulnerability to fire damage.

entries.name: Spider Climb:
entries: You can climb and cling to difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

entries.name: Scorpion Sting:
entries: You can spend your action to bite or sting a creature within 5 ft of you. That creature must make a Constitution saving throw. It takes {@damage 2d10} poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that fails its save against this effect is Poisoned until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Psychic
entries: Your eyes turn white as a third, glowing eye opens on your forehead.

entries.name: Iron Mind:
entries: You are immune to psychic damage and have vulnerability to force damage.

entries.name: Maddening Whispers:
entries: Any creature that makes a concentration check within 10 ft of you has disadvantage on the roll.

entries.name: Psychic Scream:
entries: You can spend your action to create a 15 ft cone of psychic energy extending from you in a direction of your choice. Each creature in range must make a Wisdom saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d6} psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that fails its save against this effect falls prone.

entries.name: Radiant
entries: Your skin glows with a shimmering, yellow-white light.

entries.name: Blessed Body:
entries: You are immune to radiant damage and have vulnerability to necrotic damage.

entries.name: Light Incarnate:
entries: You emit bright light in a 30 ft radius and dim light for an additional 30 ft.

entries.name: Solar Flare:
entries: You can spend your action to create a 15 ft cone of radiant light extending from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in range must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d6} radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that fails its save against this effect is {@condition Blinded} until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Slashing
entries: Sharp, metallic blades cover your body.

entries.name: Sparking Daisy:
entries: You gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks.

entries.name: Knifeblade:
entries: You can climb and cling to difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

entries.name: Spiral Hollow:
entries: You can spend your action to spin in a whirlwind of blades. Each creature within 10 ft of you must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d8} slashing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Thunder
entries: Your voice is booming and sound becomes heavily distorted around you.

entries.name: Bass Blood:
entries: You are immune to thunder damage and have vulnerability to force damage.

entries.name: Deafening Aura:
entries: Any creature that ends its turn within 10 ft of you is {@condition Deafened} until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Sonic Boom:
entries: You can spend your action to create a 10 ft radius sphere of sound centered on yourself. Each creature in that area (excluding yourself) must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d8} thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron
entries: You have made a pact with an otherworldly patron, a mighty inhabitant of another plane of existence—not a god, but almost {@i godlike} in its power.
Patrons grant you access to eldritch powers and invocations, but they expect significant favors in return—woe betide the warlock who dares to turn their back on their patron's demands.
Whatever your craving, this chapter introduces a variety of patrons for you to strike a bargain with. Make your pact and gain eldritch power.
Choose an Otherworldly Patron. You gain features from your Otherworldly Patron at 1st, 2nd, 6th, and 10th-level.

entries.name: Demands
entries: Each patron has a set of three guiding agendas—its demands—that help to direct you in the service of your patron. Honor these demands to gain—and maintain—the favor of your patron.

entries.name: Eldritch Favor:
entries: If you make a notable sacrifice in the service of a demand, your patron may bless you with eldritch favor. You can hold a maximum number of eldritch favors at one time equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum 1). On your turn, as a free action, you may spend one eldritch favor to do one of the following:

items: {@b Gain Stamina:} Regain 1 expended hit die.
{@b Gain Power:} Regain 1 expended 1st-level spell slot.
{@b Twist Fate:} Reroll 1 ability check, attack roll, or saving throw. You must accept the second result.
{@b Cause Pain:} Reroll all damage dice of an attack you have just made. You may accept either result.
{@b Forgiveness:} Forgive one transgression you have made.

entries.name: Transgression:
entries: If your patron decides that you have actively broken or rejected a demand, some of your eldritch power may be stripped away for a time.
Roll a {@dice d6} and check the Transgression table below to find out which class feature you lose access to, rerolling any result that doesn't fully apply to you.

entries.name: Penance:
entries: If you have transgressed, you will have to perform a penance to regain your patron's favor. The scale of this penance may vary depending on the severity of your transgression, but some common forms include:

items: {@b Offering:} You make an offering of goods, knowledge, coin, or time in your patron's name.
{@b Confess:} You confess your transgression to a higher-ranking agent of your patron and are forgiven.
{@b Worship:} You spend a period of time in dedicated worship of your patron.
{@b Serve:} You undertake an eldritch quest in the service of your patron and their agenda.
{@b Sacrifice:} You give up something of significant personal value.

entries: If your penance is accepted, you regain one lost feature.

entries.name: Patron Spells
entries: Your patron offers you a unique list of spells—its patron spells. You may add these the list of warlock spells you can learn.

entries.name: Pact Boon
entries: To mark the initiation of your pact bargain, you are rewarded with a {@variantrule Pact Boons|GCC|boon} from your patron—an eldritch weapon, a book of forbidden secrets, a trinket that summons a bound familiar, a wand of destructive power, etc. You may choose one boon from the list of {@filter Pact Boons|optionalfeatures|Source=GCC|Feature Type=PB}.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus:
entries: For as long as you are holding or wearing it, your pact boon acts as a spellcasting focus for your warlock spells.

classFeature.name: Pact Magic
entries: The pact you have struck with your patron has given you the ability to cast spells.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know two cantrips of your choice from the warlock spell list.

entries.name: Learning New Cantrips:
entries: You learn additional warlock cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the {@i Cantrips Known} column of the Class Features (Warlock) table.

entries.name: Replacing Known Cantrips:
entries: When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the warlock cantrips you know and replace it with another cantrip from the warlock spell list.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Class Features (Warlock) table shows how many spell slots you have. The table also shows what the level of those slots is—all of your spell slots are the same level. To cast one of your warlock spells of 1st-level or higher, you must expend a spell slot. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, when you are 5th-level, you have two 3rd-level spell slots. To cast the 1st-level spell thunderwave, you must spend one of those slots, and you cast it as a 3rd-level spell.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-level and Higher
entries: At 1st-level, you know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the warlock spell list.

entries.name: Learning New Spells:
entries: The {@i Spells Known} column of the Class Features (Warlock) table shows when you learn more warlock spells of your choice of 1st-level and higher. A spell you choose must be of a level no higher than your maximum {@i Slot Level}.
When you reach 6th-level, for example, you learn a new warlock spell, which can be 1st, 2nd, or 3rd-level.

entries.name: Replacing Known Spells:
entries: When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the warlock spells you know and replace it with another spell from the warlock spell list, which also must be no higher than your maximum {@i Slot Level}.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your warlock spells. Use your Intelligence modifier to determine the saving throw DC or attack modifier for a warlock spell you cast.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You use an arcane focus or your pact boon item as a spellcasting focus for your warlock spells.

entries.name: Eldritch Versatility
entries: When you finish a long rest, you may replace one of your known warlock spells (including cantrips) with another spell from the warlock spell list. The new spell must be of the same spell level as the spell you replace.

classFeature.name: Sacrificial Bargain
entries: When you cast a warlock spell of 1st-level or higher, you may spend a number of hit die equal to your warlock spell level to cast the spell without expending a spell slot. If the spell can't be cast at a higher level, you may instead spend a number of hit die equal to the spell's maximum casting level.
You can use this feature up to three times. You regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Invocations
entries: You gain two {@filter eldritch invocations|optionalfeatures|Source=GCC|Feature Type=EI} of your choice. When you gain certain warlock levels, you gain additional invocations of your choice—as shown in the {@i Invocations Known} column of the Class Features (Warlock) table.

entries.name: Replacing Invocations:
entries: When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the invocations you know and replace it with another invocation that you could learn at that level.

entries.name: Patron Invocations
entries: You gain access to six unique invocations from your Otherworldly Patron. Add these to your list of {@filter Eldritch Invocation|optionalfeatures|Source=GCC|Feature Type=EI} options.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron Feature
entries: At 2nd level, you gain a feature from your Patron.

classFeature.name: Pact Boon Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain an additional feature from your Pact Boon.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Pact Boon Feature
entries: At 5th level, you gain an additional feature from your Pact Boon.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature from your Patron.

classFeature.name: Pact Boon Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain an additional feature from your Pact Boon.

classFeature.name: Greater Ability Score Improvement
entries: At 8th-level, you gain another ability score improvement.
You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Pact Boon Feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain an additional feature from your Pact Boon.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature from your Patron.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum
entries: You gain a spell of formidable power from your patron—choose one of the following as your mystic arcanum.
You may cast your mystic arcanum as a 6th-level spell without expending a spell slot or material components. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Spellscript
entries: You can read and write {@variantrule Spellscript|GCC}, an academic language of glyphs, symbols, and notations used by wizards to record arcane knowledge and spells.
See the {@variantrule Spellscript|GCC} section for more details about this feature.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You gain the ability to cast magic spells through careful study of spellbooks, glyphs, and arcane sigils.

entries.name: Spellbook
entries: At 1st-level, you have a spellbook into which you can record your known spells and arcane research.
See the {@variantrule Spellbooks|GCC|Spellbook} section for more details about your spellbook.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st-level, you know three cantrips of your choice from the wizard spell list. You learn additional wizard cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the {@i Cantrips Known} column of the Class Features (Wizard) table.

entries.name: Memorable:
entries: Cantrips are simple enough for you to memorize—they don't need to be recorded or prepared.

entries.name: Replacing Known Cantrips:
entries: When you gain a wizard level, you can choose one of the wizard cantrips you know and replace it with a different cantrip from the wizard spell list.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-level and Higher
entries: At 1st-level, you know six 1st-level spells of your choice from the wizard spell list. Write these into your spellbook.

entries.name: Recorded Knowledge:
entries: Spells of 1st-level and higher are too complicated to be memorized by mortal minds—write these spells into your spellbook to keep them recorded.

entries.name: Learning New Spells:
entries: Each time you gain a wizard level, you can add two wizard spells of your choice to your spellbook for free. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots, as shown in the Class Features (Wizard) table.
In addition, you may find other wizard spells—such as on scrolls and in spellbooks—on your adventures. If you can decipher their spellscript, you may be able to write them into your own spellbook.

entries.name: Preparing Spells
entries: You must prepare the list of wizard spells that you can cast, choosing from your list of recorded wizard spells.

entries.name: Preparing Your Spell List:
entries: Choose a number of wizard spells from your spellbook equal to your Intelligence modifier + your wizard level (minimum of one spell).
Prepared spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and you must be able to access the spells in your spellbook as you're preparing them.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells:
entries: You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of wizard spells requires time: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Number of Spells:
entries: your Intelligence modifier + your wizard level (minimum of one spell)

entries.name: Casting Spells
entries: The Class Features (Wizard) table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your prepared wizard spells of 1st-level and higher.

To cast one of your prepared spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. Casting a spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells, and you regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your wizard spells. Use your Intelligence modifier to set the saving throw DC or attack modifier for any wizard spell you cast.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast a wizard spell as a ritual if (a) the spell has the ritual tag and (b) you have access to the spell in your spellbook. You don't need to have a spell prepared first to cast it as a ritual.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use your spellbook or an arcane focus as a spellcasting focus for your wizard spells.

entries.name: Arcane Versatility
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can choose one of the wizard cantrips you know and replace it with a different cantrip from the wizard spell list.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition
entries: Choose an {@i Arcane Tradition}. You gain features from your Arcane Tradition at 1st, 3rd, 6th, and 10th-level.

entries.name: Favored & Clashing Magic
entries: Magic spells are categorized into eight traditional schools of arcane power. As you begin to train in your Arcane Tradition, some of these schools become easier—or more difficult—for you to learn and master.
At 1st-level, you gain one {@i Favored} and one {@i Clashing} school of magic from your Arcane Tradition, with an associated feature for each.

classFeature.name: Arcane Recovery
entries: When you finish a short rest, you can recover some expended spell slots by studying your spellbook. The spell slots must have a combined level equal to or less than half your wizard level (rounded up), and none of the slots can be 6th-level or higher.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Spell Research
entries: As a student of the arcane, you are able to learn new wizard spells in your downtime through careful study, research, and experimentation.
See the {@variantrule Spell Research|GCC} section for more details about this feature.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your Arcane Tradition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Spellscript Savant
entries: You have learned a new technique to improve the quality of your spellscript and spell writing. Choose one of the options listed below.

entries.name: Greater Spellscript Savant:
entries: At 8th-level, choose an additional feature. You can't choose the same feature more than once unless specified otherwise.

entries.name: Compression
entries: You have learned how to use notations more efficiently in your writing. When you write spellscript, you can spend one additional hour per spell level to compress your text.

Compressed spellscript takes up half as much physical space as it normally would (rounded up) and—when calculating your spellbook's {@i magical capacity}—counts as half its normal spell level (rounded up).

entries.name: Encryption
entries: You can encrypt your spellscript, making it impossible for other wizards to decipher without your personal cypher.
When writing new spellscript, you can spend 1 additional hour per spell level to encrypt your text.

entries.name: Decryption:
entries: You can't prepare a spell by reading from encrypted spellscript—you must read from a decrypted copy. It takes 1 additional hour per spell level to decipher your own encrypted text.

entries.name: Physical Cypher:
entries: The cypher for your encryption is a set of arcane codes and substitutions too complicated to memorize—it must be written down somewhere, and you must be able to access it when encrypting or decrypting your spellscript.

entries.name: Potent Glyphs
entries: You have learned how to use cost-effective notations when writing spellscript. Spells count as one level lower than normal when calculating how much gold you must spend to write them.
You can choose this option multiple times.

entries.name: Shorthand
entries: You have learned how to read and write in arcane shorthand. You can write spellscript, decipher spellscript, and prepare spells in half the usual time (rounded up).

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature from your Arcane Tradition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by +2, or two ability scores of your choice by +1. You can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Signature Spell
entries: Choose one 1st-level wizard spell from your spellbook to be your Signature Spell. While your signature spell is prepared, you may cast it as 1st-level spell without expending a spell slot.
You can do this a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature from your Arcane Tradition.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Berserker
entries: The {@i Path of the Berserker} is a path of untrammeled fury, slick with blood. Your rage is a means to an end—that end being brutal violence.
As you enter the berserker's rage, you thrill in the wild chaos and bloodshed of battle—heedless of your own health or well-being.
Add the following four brutalities to your list of brutality options: bloodlust, charge, ferocity, and relentless.

entries.name: Bloodlust
entries: When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with a melee weapon attack while raging, you can attempt to move and attack another creature. You may spend a bonus action to move up to half your speed towards another creature. If the creature is (a) within your reach and (b) your original attack would hit it, that creature takes {@damage 1d6} damage. The damage is of the same type dealt by the original attack, and can't exceed the total damage dealt by the original attack.

entries.name: Greater Bloodlust:
entries: (5th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 2d8}.

entries.name: Superior Bloodlust:
entries: (9th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 2d8} to {@damage 3d10}.

entries.name: Charge
entries: When you move at least 20 ft straight towards a creature while raging and hit it with a melee weapon attack, you can deal {@damage 1d6} extra damage with your attack. The damage is of the same type dealt by the original attack, and can't exceed the total damage dealt by the original attack.

entries.name: Greater Charge:
entries: (5th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 2d8}.

entries.name: Superior Charge:
entries: (9th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 2d8} to {@damage 3d10}.

entries.name: Ferocity
entries: When you make an ability check and use {@skill Athletics} or {@skill Intimidation}, you can roll {@dice 1d6} and add it to the result. You can wait until after you roll your check before deciding to use this brutality, but you must decide before the GM says whether your check succeeds or fails.

entries.name: Greater Ferocity:
entries: (5th-level) Your bonus increases from {@dice 1d6} to {@dice 1d8}.

entries.name: Superior Ferocity:
entries: (9th-level) Your bonus increases from {@dice 1d8} to {@dice 1d10}.

entries.name: Relentless
entries: When you are reduced to 0 hit points while raging but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. You can't use this brutality again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Greater Relentless:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this brutality two times per long rest.

entries.name: Superior Relentless:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this brutality three times per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Frenzy
entries: When you rage, you may choose to go into a frenzy. If you do so, for the duration of your rage you can make one additional melee weapon attack once per turn when you take the Attack action.
When your frenzied rage ends, you must immediately do one of the following:

items: Spend one of your hit die.
Spend two points of brutality.
Suffer one level of exhaustion.

subclassFeature.name: Mindless Rage
entries: You can't be charmed or frightened while raging. If you are charmed or frightened when you enter your rage, the effect is suspended for the duration of the rage.

subclassFeature.name: Intimidating Presence
entries: You can use your action to frighten someone. Choose one creature that you can see within 30 feet of you. If the creature can see or hear you, it must make a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) to avoid being frightened.

entries.name: If the Creature Succeeds:
entries: The creature is immune to your {@i Intimidating Presence} for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: If the Creature Fails:
entries: The creature is {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn. On subsequent turns, you can spend 1 action to extend the duration of this effect on one frightened creature until the end of your next turn. This effect ends if the creature ends its turn out of line of sight or more than 60 feet away from you.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Brawler
entries: To barbarians on the Path of the Brawler, a weapon is merely a tool for the weak. These barbarians embrace a primal fury that allows them to use their body as the weapon, and give them the tools to push their enemies around with brutal efficiency.
Add the following four brutalities to your list of brutality options: Constrict, Drop, Resilience, Thrash.

entries.name: Constrict
entries: When you hit a creature you have grappled and you have a hand free, you can attempt to restrict them further. The target must make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (the target may choose which). On a failed save, the target is constricted and gains the {@condition Restrained} condition until the grapple ends.

entries.name: Greater Constrict
entries: Starting at 5th level, you can attempt to restrict a creature without a free hand.

entries.name: Superior Constrict
entries: Starting at 9th level, when you successfully constrict a creature they are also knocked {@condition Prone}.

entries.name: Drop
entries: When you fall and hit a creature with a melee weapon attack on the same turn, you can use the momentum to deal extra damage with your attack. If you fell at least 5 ft, your attack deals an additional {@damage 1d6} damage. The damage is of the same type dealt by the original attack, and cannot exceed the total damage dealt by the original attack.

entries.name: Greater Drop
entries: Starting at 5th level, the damage increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 2d8}.

entries.name: Superior Drop
entries: Starting at 9th level, the damage increases from {@damage 2d8} to {@damage 3d10}.

entries.name: Resilience
entries: When you take damage while raging and under half of your maximum hit points, you can reduce the damage dealt by {@dice 1d6}. This reduction applies after resistance.

entries.name: Greater Resilience
entries: Starting at 5th level, your reduction increases from {@dice 1d6} to {@dice 1d8}.

entries.name: Superior Resilience
entries: Starting at 9th level, your reduction increases from {@dice 1d6} to {@dice 1d10}.

entries.name: Thrash
entries: When you hit a creature you are grappling with a melee weapon attack, you can attempt to damage it further or cleave to another creature you are grappling. Choose either the creature you hit with the original attack, or another creature you are grappling. If the original attack roll would hit the creature, that creature takes {@damage 1d6} damage. The damage is of the same type dealt by the original attack, and cannot exceed the total damage dealt by the original attack.

entries.name: Greater Thrash
entries: Starting at 5th level, the damage increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 2d8}.

entries.name: Superior Thrash
entries: Starting at 9th level, the damage increases from {@damage 2d8} to {@damage 3d10}.

subclassFeature.name: Brawler's Fury
entries: At 3rd level, you can use your rage to turn yourself into a fearsome weapon. While raging your unarmed attacks that use Strength deal {@damage 1d10} bludgeoning damage and you can use your bonus action to take the grapple or shove action.
The damage of your unarmed strikes increases to {@damage 1d12} when you reach 9th level.

subclassFeature.name: Titan Wrestler
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to topple giants. While raging you can grapple or shove creatures up to two sizes larger than you. In addition, when you successfully grapple or shove a creature, or stop a creature escaping a grapple, you can deal damage to them equal to your rage damage.

subclassFeature.name: Grabbing Riposte
entries: When you reach 10th level, your mastery of grappling is such that you can grab those who fail to strike you. When a Large or smaller creature within your reach misses a melee attack against you, you can use your reaction to attempt to grapple the creature.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Conqueror
entries: The {@i Path of the Conqueror} is a path of authority and subjugation. You are destined—or determined—to rule. Where you lead, others follow. Where you wage war, others flee—or fall.
Add the following four brutalities to your list of brutality options: decree, command, prevail, and proclaim.

entries.name: Decree
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can decree that an ally moves. Choose one friendly creature that is (a) within 30 ft of you or the creature you hit, (b) can hear you, and (c) has a movement speed greater than 0—that creature may spend its reaction to move up to 10 ft. This movement does not provoke opportunity attacks from the creature you hit.

entries.name: Greater Decree:
entries: (5th-level) The distance increases from 10 ft to 15 ft.

entries.name: Superior Decree:
entries: (9th-level) The distance increases from 15 ft to 20 ft.

entries.name: Command
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can command a nearby ally. Choose one friendly creature that can see and hear you. That creature may spend its reaction to make a weapon attack against the same target. If the attack hits, it deals an additonal {@damage 1d6} damage.

entries.name: Greater Command:
entries: (5th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 1d8}.

entries.name: Superior Command:
entries: (9th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 1d8} to {@damage 1d10}.

entries.name: Prevail
entries: When an ally misses with a weapon attack, you can order them to prevail and try again. If your ally can see and hear you, that ally can reroll their attack—if the attack hits, it deals {@damage 1d6} extra damage.

entries.name: Greater Prevail:
entries: (5th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 1d8}.

entries.name: Superior Prevail:
entries: (9th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 1d8} to {@damage 1d10}.

entries.name: Proclaim
entries: When you make an ability check and use Persuasion or Intimidation, you can roll {@dice 1d6} and add it to the result. You can wait until after you roll your check before deciding to use this maneuver, but you must decide before the GM says whether your check succeeds or fails.

entries.name: Greater Proclaim:
entries: (5th-level) Your bonus increases from {@dice 1d6} to {@dice 1d8}.

entries.name: Superior Proclaim:
entries: (9th-level) Your bonus increases from {@dice 1d8} to {@dice 1d10}.

subclassFeature.name: Voice of Authority
entries: You gain proficiency in either a) {@skill Intimidation} or b) {@skill Persuasion}. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for ability checks with that skill.

subclassFeature.name: Subjugate the Fallen
entries: You can turn a fallen enemy into subjugated vassal by offering them a choice—serve me or {@i die}.

Once per turn, while you are raging and would reduce a Medium or smaller creature to 0 hit points with a melee weapon attack, you can attempt to {@i subjugate} it. The creature must be able to see, hear, and understand you. If it resists, it must make a Wisdom saving throw against a DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier. The creature gains a saving bonus equal to half it's CR (rounded down).
If it fails—or otherwise chooses to conceed—the creature is reduced to 1 hit point and is {@i Subjugated} by you, becoming your vassal.

entries.name: Saving Throw
entries.text: Wisdom modifier + half your CR (rounded down)

entries.name: Subjugated
entries: You are subjugated by another creature. You are their vassal, obeying their orders for as long as your loyalty holds true.

items: {@b Tame:} The subjugator has advantage on any ability check to interact socially with you.
{@b Reverent:} You can't attack your subjugator or target them with harmful abilities or magical effects.
{@b Obediant:} You follow the commands of your subjugator.
{@b Loyal:} When you are first subjugated, you gain {@dice 1d4} loyalty points. When your loyalty is reduced to 0, you are no longer subjugated.

entries: You can subjugate one creature at a time, and you may dismiss a vassal from your service as a bonus action. When you dismiss a vassal in this fashion, it loses one point of loyalty towards you.

entries.name: Immunities:
entries: Undead creatures, constructs, and creatures that are immune to {@condition Frightened} automatically succeed on their attempt to resist subjugation.

entries.name: Taking Actions
entries: Your vassal acts immediately after your turn, following your commands as best it can. If you are incapacitated or otherwise absent, the vassal acts on its own as befits its current loyalty.

subclassFeature.name: Loyalty
entries: Loyalty is a measurement of trust and obediance—the more loyalty your vassal has towards you, the more likely it is to follow your commands and resist stabbing you in the back at the first opportunity.

When you first subjugate a vassal, it has {@dice 1d4} points of loyalty towards you. A vassal can have a maximum amount of loyalty equal to your barbarian level, and that loyalty determines its attitude towards you—resentful, accepting, motivated, or devoted.

entries.caption: Attitudes
rows: {@b Rebellious:} The vassal is no longer subjugated by you—so watch your back.

entries: {@b Resentful:} The vassal resents being subjugated by you and won't obey life-threatening commands.
If it refuses to follow an order, you must make a DC 16 Charisma (Persuasion or Intimidation) ability check to command it.
{@b Tolerant:} The vassal is more accepting of your dominion, though it will still preserve its own life.
If it refuses to follow an order, you must make a DC 14 Charisma (Persuasion or Intimidation) ability check to command it.
{@b Motivated:} The vassal actively wants you to succeed in your efforts.
If it refuses to follow an order, you must make a DC 12 Charisma (Persuasion or Intimidation) ability check to command it.
{@b Devoted:} The vassal is devoted to your cause and will put itself in harms way at your command.
If you take damage from a weapon attack while adjacent to the vassal, it can spend its reaction to take the damage on your behalf.

entries.name: Vassal Independance
entries: A subjugated vassal retains its own will, wants, and wishes. Though it may follow your commands, some orders may be so antithetical that it will always refuse or perform badly—no matter how high you roll.
Keep in mind the character of your vassal—subjugate creatures that are a good match for your own goals, attitudes, and alignment.

entries.name: Gaining Loyalty
entries: Loyalty is gained through kindness, kinship, and material rewards. A vassal gains one point of loyalty when:

items: It is given a {@i meaningful} reward by its subjugator.
The subjugator helps it to complete a personal goal.
It is treated exceptionally well or made to feel valued.

entries.name: Losing Loyalty
entries: Loyalty is lost through greed, insensitivity, and vanity. A vassal loses one point of loyalty when:

items: It takes damage from its subjugator or their allies.
It is made to feel unvalued or unwanted.
It is reduced to 0 hit points.
It is made to act against something it cares about—a person, a faction, a belief, etc.

entries.name: Natural Rebels:
entries: Chaotic creatures are, by their nature, disinclied to follow orders and remain loyal. When a creature with a {@i chaotic} alignment loses loyalty, it loses twice as much as it normally would.

subclassFeature.name: Rule of Iron
entries: When you take the {@action Attack} action while you are raging, your vassal can spend its reaction to make a weapon attack.

subclassFeature.name: Conqueror's Will
entries: You roar a conquering command to your allies. As a bonus action, choose up to twelve creatures within 60 ft of you that can both see and hear you. Until the start of your next turn, these creatures gain advantage on attack rolls and saving throws.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Fanatic
entries: The {@i Path of the Fanatic} is a path of zealous belief and fervor. With your righteous rage, you punish the blasphemous and inspire the faithful.

subclassFeature.name: Fanaticism
entries: You believe in someone—or {@i something}—with a burning passion. Choose one of the following damage types to represent the power—and theme—of your fanaticism:

items: Acid
Cold
Fire
Force
Necrotic
Lightning
Poison
Psychic
Radiant
Thunder

entries: Add the following four brutalities to your list of brutality options: convert, judge, preach, and punish.

entries.name: Convert
entries: When an adjacent Large or smaller creature makes a weapon attack against you, you can spend a reaction to convert it before it makes the attack roll. The creature must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition Charmed} by you until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Greater Convert:
entries: (5th-level) You can use this brutality against Huge creatures.

entries.name: Superior Convert:
entries: (9th-level) You can use this brutality against Gargantuan creatures.

entries.name: Judge
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can mark the creature with a fanatical judgement. Until the end of your next turn, the first time the creature either a) makes a weapon attack or b) casts a spell, it takes 1d6 fanaticism damage. This damage occurs after the inciting action takes place, and a creature can be marked by only one judgement at a time.

entries.name: Greater Judge:
entries: (5th-level) The damage increases from 1d6 to 2d8.

entries.name: Superior Judge:
entries: (9th-level) The damage increases from 2d8 to 3d10.

entries.name: Preach
entries: When you make an ability check and use {@skill Religion} or {@skill Persuasion}, you can roll {@dice 1d6} and add it to the result. You can wait until after you roll your check before deciding to use this brutality, but you must decide before the GM says whether your check succeeds or fails.

entries.name: Greater Preach:
entries: (5th-level) Your bonus increases from 1d6 to 1d8.

entries.name: Superior Preach:
entries: (9th-level) Your bonus increases from 1d8 to 1d10.

entries.name: Punish
entries: When a creature hits either a) you or b) an ally within 10 ft of you with a weapon attack, you can spend your reaction to make a weapon attack against the creature. If the attack hits, you deal an extra {@damage 1d6} fanaticism damage.

entries.name: Greater Punish:
entries: (5th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 1d6} to {@damage 2d8}.

entries.name: Superior Punish:
entries: (9th-level) The damage increases from {@damage 2d8} to {@damage 3d10}.

subclassFeature.name: Righteous Rage
entries: When you enter a rage, you may choose one of the following righteous effects:

items: {@b Righteous Fury:} Once during your turn, when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can deal additional fanaticism damage equal to {@damage 1d6} + your barbarian level.
{@b Righteous Protection:} You have immunity to the damage type of your fanaticism.

entries: This effect lasts for the duration of your rage. You may spend one hit die and a bonus action during your rage to change the currently active effect.

subclassFeature.name: Unrelenting
entries: When you are reduced to 0 hit points while raging but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. In addition, you gain temporary hit points equal to four times your barbarian level.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Fanatical Crusade
entries: You roar a battle cry to inspire fanaticism in your allies. As a bonus action, choose up to twelve creatures within 60 ft of you that can both see and hear you. For the next minute, these creatures deal an additional {@damage 1d6} fanaticism damage the first time they hit a target with a weapon attack each turn.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: College of Dance
entries: You are a bard of the {@i College of Dance} and you know how to turn heads on the dancefloor. Whether in a fine royal court or a dark and sunken dungeon, you inspire and enflame with physical prowess, shaping the elements of movement—space, time, and force—into magic.

subclassFeature.name: Collegiate Pledges
entries: You—and other bards of your college—are guided by the following collegiate pledges:

items: {@b Be Confident:} To be the best dancer, you must be confident in yourself and your abilities. Practice often, stay limber, and be bold. When you dance, dance like nobody's watching.
{@b Inspire Emotion:} Dancing can inspire strong emotions—passion, excitement, love, and joy. Use your dances to rouse your allies, turn enemies into friends, and build stronger social connections.
{@b Encourage Others:} Everyone can dance—with the right encouragement and motivation. Help others to dance to the music playing in their heart. Be a passionate advocate and a patient teacher.

subclassFeature.name: Collegiate Inspiration
entries: You learn how to use your knowledge of dance to inspire and encourage your allies.

entries.name: Let's Dance
entries: You can spend your bonus action and one point of composition to evoke movement and motion in your allies.
Choose one of the following dances and a number of creatures within 30 ft of you equal to your Charisma modifier—each creature gains the benefit of your dance.
This effect lasts for up to 1 minute, and a creature can benefit from only one dance at a time. You must be unarmored and not wearing a shield to use this feature.

items: {@b Dance of War:} You gain +1 AC. If you are either a) unarmored or b) wearing light armor, you instead gain +2 AC.
{@b Dance of Water:} You gain advantage on Dexterity saving throws and Performance ability checks related to dance.
{@b Dance of Wind:} You gain +5 ft movement speed. If you are either a) unarmored or b) wearing light armor, you instead gain +10 ft movement.

subclassFeature.name: White Knuckles
entries: While you are not wearing any armor and not wielding a shield, your armor class equals 10 + your Constitution modifier + your Dexterity modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Body Language
entries: When you cast a bard spell, you can replace any verbal components with somatic components. You must be unarmored and not wielding a shield to use this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Dancing Mad
entries: You compel a creature to dance with you. Spend a bonus action and choose one adjacent creature. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw—if it fails, the creature is both {@condition Charmed} and {@condition Grappled} by you until the end of its next turn.

While these conditions are in effect, you control the creature's movement. Your movement speed is halved and, when you move, you can pull the creature with you. This movement does not provoke opportunity attacks.
Creatures that are immune to {@condition Charmed} are immune to this effect. If you cease to be adjacent to the creature, the effect ends.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Tribute
entries: You gain proficiency in either a) {@skill Acrobatics} or b) {@skill Performance}. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for ability checks with that skill.

subclassFeature.name: Lose Yourself to Dance
entries: You unlock the rhythm of a creature's heart, inspiring it to dance. Spend an action and choose one creature that you can see within 30 ft. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw—if it fails, the creature begins to dance in place for up to one minute.

A dancing creature must use all its movement to dance without leaving its space and has disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws and attack rolls. While the target is affected by this spell, other creatures have advantage on attack rolls against it. If the creature takes damage from a source other than itself, the effect ends immediately.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: College of Lore
entries: You are a bard of the {@i College of Lore} and you know a little something about {@i almost} anything. From scholarly tomes in ancient ruins to peasant tales in dingy taverns, you collect fragments of knowledge from all corners of the world and spin local rumor into world-changing truth.

subclassFeature.name: Collegiate Pledges
entries: You—and other bards of your college—are guided by the following collegiate pledges:

items: {@b Find the Truth:} Inside every rumor hides a little truth. Collect stories wherever you go and assemble little truths into big discoveries.
{@b Fight Corruption:} Corrupt authorities are known to obscure truth and suppress knowledge. Expose and subvert these authorities so that the truth can shine.
{@b Create History:} You are not an archivist, trapping lore in books to hide on dusty shelves. You are a bard. Use your knowledge to change the world.

subclassFeature.name: Collegiate Inspiration
entries: You learn how to use your wit to distract, confuse, and otherwise sap the confidence and competence of others.

entries.name: Cutting Words
entries: When a creature that you can see within 60 feet of you makes (a) an attack roll, (b) an ability check, or (c) a damage roll, you can use your reaction to spend one point of composition and unleash some {@i Cutting Words}.

Roll your {@i Bardic Inspiration} die and subtract the number rolled from the creature's roll. You can choose to use this feature after the creature makes its roll, but it must be before (a) the GM determines whether the attack roll or ability check succeeds or fails, or (b) the creature deals its damage.

items: {@b I'm Not Listening:} You can't target a creature that either a) is immune to Charmed or b) can't hear you.
