entries.name: No Bounds
entries: You can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

optionalfeature.name: Essence of Defense
entries: {@b Shrug off your prey's attacks with your natural defences}

items: {@b Speed:} 10 ft
{@b Size:} Tiny
{@b Skill:} Athletics

entries.name: Durable
entries: Gain temporary hit points equal to your druid level times four (x4). You lose these temporary hit points when you end this wild shape.
This temporary hit point bonus increases with the size category of your skin: small (x6), medium (x7), large (x8), huge (x9), and gargantuan (x10).

entries.name: Relentless
entries: The first time you are reduced to 0 hit points while wearing this wild shape, you are reduced to 1 hit point instead. You can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Essence of Dexterity
entries: {@b Strike at your prey with opportune precision.}

items: {@b Speed:} 20 ft
{@b Size:} Tiny
{@b Skill:} Acobatics

entries.name: Precision
entries: You may use your Dexterity modifier for both your unarmed attack and unarmed damage rolls.

entries.name: Sneak Attack
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a creature with a weapon attack and you have advantage, you deal additional damage equal to your unarmed damage die.

optionalfeature.name: Essence of Disguise
entries: {@b Remain hidden from your prey.}

items: {@b Speed:} 15 ft
{@b Size:} Tiny
{@b Skill:} Stealth

entries.name: Escape Artist
entries: You can {@action Hide} as a bonus action.

entries.name: Camoflage
entries: When you remain motionless, you are indistinguishable from your surroundings to any creature that is larger than you.

optionalfeature.name: Essence of Hunger
entries: {@b Constrict and Devour your prey.}

items: {@b Speed:} 10 ft
{@b Size:} Tiny
{@b Skill:} Perception

entries.name: Constrict
entries: When you hit an adjacent creature with a melee weapon attack, you can attempt to constrict it. The creature must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or be grappled by you.
The creature must be at most one size category larger than you. You can constrict only one creature at a time.

entries.name: Devour
entries: When you hit a constricted creature with a melee weapon attack, you can attempt to devour it. The creature must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or be devoured by you.

A devoured creature is blinded and restrained, has total cover against attacks and other effects outside you, and takes acid damage at the start of its turns equal to your unarmed damage die. Until the creature is reduced to 0 hit points, your speed is halved.
The creature must be smaller than you, and you can devour one creature at a time. You are vulnerable to slashing and piercing damage dealt by the creature.
You can regurgitate a devoured creature—or its remains—into an adjacent space as a bonus action, and you automatically regurgitate a devoured creature when you end your wild shape.

optionalfeature.name: Essence of the Pack
entries: {@b Surround your prey and fight with your pack.}

items: {@b Speed:} 15 ft
{@b Size:} Tiny
{@b Skill:} Perception

entries.name: Sturdy
entries: You have advantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws against effects that knock you prone.

entries.name: Pack Tactics
entries: You have advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of your allies is within 5 ft of it and your ally isn't incapacitated.

optionalfeature.name: Essence of Strength
entries: {@b Overpower your prey with savage strength}

items: {@b Speed:} 15 ft
{@b Size:} Tiny
{@b Skill:} Athletics

entries.name: Animal Rage
entries: Your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19-20.

entries.name: Savage Attack
entries: When you critically hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon's damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.

optionalfeature.name: Essence of Speed
entries: {@b Dash past the enemies.}

items: {@b Speed:} 20 ft
{@b Size:} Tiny
{@b Skill:} Acrobatics

entries.name: Fast Runner
entries: You can {@action Dash} as a bonus action.

entries.name: Charge
entries: If you move at least 20 ft in a straight toward a creature and hit it with an unarmed attack on the same turn, the creature takes additional damage equal to your unarmed damage die.

In addition, if the creature is at most one size category larger than you, the creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or be knocked prone.

optionalfeature.name: Essence of Tracking
entries: {@b No prey can hide from your keen senses.}

items: {@b Speed:} 15 ft
{@b Size:} Tiny
{@b Skill:} Perception

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You gain darkvision (60 ft).

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks.

optionalfeature.name: Essence of Swimming
entries: {@b Hunt your prey in the seas}

items: {@b Speed:} 15 ft
{@b Size:} Tiny
{@b Skill:} Perception

entries.name: Natural Swimmer
entries: You gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed. Your walking speed is then reduced to 0.

entries.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: You have advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

optionalfeature.name: Essence of Flight
entries: {@b Track your prey from the skies}

items: {@b Speed:} 15 ft
{@b Size:} Tiny
{@b Skill:} Perception

entries.name: Natural Flight
entries: You gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed.

entries.name: Dive
entries: If you are flying and dive at least 20 ft straight towards a creature and hit it with a melee weapon attack, the attack deals additional damage equal to your unarmed damage die.

optionalfeature.name: Careful Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that forces other creatures to make a saving throw, you can protect some of those creatures from the spell's full force.
Spend 1 sorcery point and choose a number of those creatures up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one creature). A chosen creature automatically succeeds on its saving throw.

optionalfeature.name: Heightened Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a saving throw to resist its effects, you can spend 3 sorcery points to give one target of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Inverted Spell
entries: When you roll damage for a spell with an elemental effect, you can spend 1 sorcery point to invert the type of that damage. There are five known elemental pairings:

items: Fire / Cold
Radiant / Necrotic
Lightning / Thunder
Poison / Acid
Psychic / Force

entries.name: Compound:
entries: You can combine {@i inverted spell} with other metamagics during the casting of a spell.

optionalfeature.name: Quickened Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 action, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the casting time to 1 bonus action for this casting.

optionalfeature.name: Subtle Spell
entries: When you cast a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to cast it without any somatic or verbal components.

optionalfeature.name: Twinned Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that (a) targets only one creature and (b) doesn't have a range of self, you can spend a number of sorcery points equal to the spell level to target a second creature in range with the same spell (1 sorcery point if the spell is a cantrip).

entries.name: Single-target Only:
entries: A spell can be twinned only if it is incapable of targeting more than one creature at the spell's casting level.
For example, {@spell Magic Missile} and {@spell Scorching Ray} aren't eligible, but {@spell Ray of Frost} and {@spell Chromatic Orb} are.

optionalfeature.name: Chromatic Spell
entries: When you roll damage for a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to change the damage type of that spell to that of your draconic ancestry.

optionalfeature.name: Empowered Spell
entries: When you roll damage for a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll a number of the damage dice up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one). You must use the new rolls.

entries.name: Compound:
entries: You can combine {@i empowered spell} with other metamagics during the casting of a spell.

optionalfeature.name: Extended Spell
entries: When you cast a spell, you can extend either its range or duration with {@i extended spell}.

entries.name: Distance:
entries: When you cast a spell that has a range of 5 feet or greater, you can spend 1 sorcery point to double the range of the spell. Alternatively, if the spell has a range of touch, you can spend 1 sorcery point to make the range of the spell 30 feet.

entries.name: Duration:
entries: When you cast a spell that has a duration of 1 minute or longer, you can spend 1 sorcery point to double its duration, to a maximum duration of 24 hours.

optionalfeature.name: Seeking Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that attacks a creature, you can spend 2 sorcery points to add +2 to the first attack roll you make as part of that spell.

entries.name: Compound:
entries: You can combine {@i seeking spell} with other metamagics during the casting of a spell.

optionalfeature.name: Slots
entries: You spend 1 sorcery point to change the damage type of a spell to a random damage typing applied to damaging spells. You can try to guess the type that will come up for a +15 damage bonus, but if you guess wrong, -5 damage.

optionalfeature.name: Displacement
entries: After the spell has been cast and any damage or effects applied, you swap places with the target of this spell via teleport. If the target is unwilling, they may make a charisma saving throw against your DC to resist this effect. If the distance between you and the target is 30 feet the cost is 1 sorcery point. Each additional 10 feet increases the sorcery point cost by 1 to a maximum of 120 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Arcane Rebuke
entries: If a creature saves against your spell, you can spend a sorcery point to deal {@damage 1d8} force damage to that creature.

entries.name: Compound:
entries: You can combine {@i Arcane Rebuke} with other metamagics during the casting of a spell.

optionalfeature.name: Bend Luck
entries: When casting a spell you can spend 2 sorcery points to roll {@dice 1d4} and apply the number rolled as a bonus or penalty (your choice) to one of the attack rolls or saving throws. You can do so after the creature rolls but before any effects of the roll occur.

entries.name: Compound:
entries: You can combine {@i Bend Luck} with other metamagics during the casting of a spell.

optionalfeature.name: Pact of the Blade
entries: You ask your patron for physical power, and you are rewarded with an eldritch weapon.

entries.name: Pact Weapon
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 1st Level}
You gain a unique, eldritch weapon from your patron. This weapon is honed and shaped by your own mind—the stronger your intellect, the sharper your blade.
In addition, you gain proficiency with medium armor, shields, and martial weapons.

entries.name: Pact Weapon
entries: You can spend one action to summon your pact weapon into your empty hand. You can choose the form that this weapon takes each time you summon it—a dagger, a sword, a bow, etc—though it must be a form of weapon that you are proficient with.
Your weapon bears the unmistakable mark of your eldritch patron—fiendish red veins, fey vines and flowers, aberrant runes and etchings, etc.

items: {@b Eldritch Strike:} When you attack with this weapon, you can use your Intelligence modifier (instead of Strength or Dexterity) for the attack and damage rolls.
{@b Magical Origin:} This weapon counts as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.
{@b Ephemeral:} This weapon disappears if you use this feature again, if you dismiss the weapon (no action required), or if you die.
{@b Greater Pact Weapon:} Starting at 5th-level, you can attack with your pact weapon twice—instead of once—whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

entries.name: Assimilate
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 3rd Level}
You can transform a magic weapon into your pact weapon by performing a special, eldritch ritual.

The ritual takes 1 hour, during which you must be holding the weapon. You can then dismiss the weapon, shunting it into an extradimensional space—the weapon appears whenever you summon your pact weapon thereafter. You can't affect an artifact or a sentient weapon in this way.

entries.name: Breaking the Bond:
entries: The weapon ceases to be your pact weapon if either (a) you die, (b) you assimilate a different weapon, or (c) you use a 1-hour ritual to break your bond to it. The weapon appears at your feet if it is in the extradimensional space when the bond breaks.

entries.name: Eldritch Brand
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 5th Level}
You are able to mark a creature with your {@i Eldritch Brand}.

entries.name: Eldritch Brand

items: {@b Casting Time:} No action
{@b Range:} Self
{@b Components:} V
{@b Duration:} Concentration, up to 1 minute

entries: When you hit a creature with your pact weapon, you may choose to brand the creature and deal an extra {@damage 1d6} force damage per your spell slot level.

While the creature is branded, attacks with your pact weapon deal extra force damage to that creature equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). The creature also can't benefit from the {@condition Invisible} condition until the mark expires.
You may use this feature a number of times equal to your intelligence modifier, and you recover expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Translocate
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 7th Level}
If your pact weapon is within 300 feet of you, you can spend a bonus action to teleport to its location—or to the nearest unoccupied space if that location is occupied.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1), and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Banish
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 9th Level}
You are able to {@spell Banishment||Banish} a creature to the realm of your patron. You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Pact of the Blood
entries: You ask your patron for immortality, and you were rewarded with your patron's blood.

entries.name: Otherworldy Blood
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 1st Level}
Your blood has been replaced with that of an otherworldy being. It may be the blue blood of a fey, the black blood of a fiend, the golden blood of a celestial, or the foul ichor of a great old one.
Your type changes to Aberration, Celestial, Elemental, Fey, Fiend, or Undead.
Additionally, when you aren't wearing armor, your AC equals 13 + your Dexterity modifier.

entries.name: Mutations
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 3rd Level}
Whenever you finish a long rest you may choose one of the following mutations. You may only have one mutation active at a time.

entries.name: Acidic Blood
entries: When hit by a melee attack, your attacker takes acid damage equal to your Warlock level. A creature can only take damage from this feature once per turn.

entries.name: Coagulating Blood
entries: When you spend a hit die to regain hit points, you instead regain hit points as though you rolled the maximum.

entries.name: Efficient Blood
entries: You can hold your breath for twice as long and have advantage on saving throws against the Exhausted condition.

entries.name: Regulated Blood
entries: You are immune to the {@condition poisoned} condition and have resistance to poison damage. Additionally, you are naturally adapted to both hot and cold climates as described in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5|Wilderness Survival} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}.

entries.name: Defier of Death
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 5th Level}
If a spell, such as {@spell Raise Dead}, has the sole effect of restoring you to life, the caster doesn't need material components to cast the spell on you.

entries.name: Otherworldly Fortitude
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 7th Level}
Reduce any bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage that you take by your proficiency bonus, to a minimum of 1.

entries.name: Timeless
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 9th Level}

You cease aging and cannot be aged magically. This feature extends the time limit on spells which would raise you from the dead as though you were under the effects of the {@spell Gentle Repose} spell.

optionalfeature.name: Pact of the Chain
entries: You ask your patron for the ability to control others, and are rewarded with a bound familiar.

entries.name: Chained Familiar
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 1st Level}
You gain a special trinket from your patron which allows you to summon a familiar and bind it to your will.

entries.name: Chain Trinket
entries: An eldritch trinket—such as a ring, bracelet, earring, or a diadem. While you are wearing this trinket, you can cast the {@spell Find Familiar} spell as a ritual without spending material components.
Your trinket bears the unmistakable mark of your patron—fiendish red veins, fey vines and flowers, aberrant runes and etchings, etc.

items: {@b Chain Master:} When you take the Attack action, you can forgo one of your own attacks to allow your familiar to spend its reaction and make one attack of its own.
{@b I Remember:} This trinket always summons the same familiar—same name, memories, personality, etc—but you may choose its form each time it is summoned.
{@b I Serve:} Your familiar has a personality of its own—it may or may not be happy to serve you. But whatever its attitude, the familiar must obey the command of whomever wears the trinket.

entries: Your familiar is shaped by your eldritch whims. At 1st-level, choose one of the {@i Favored Familiar} options. Your familiar may take the form of any tiny creature that has (a) your chosen creature type and (b) a maximum CR of 1/8. As you gain warlock levels, your familiar can take on more substantial—and powerful—forms.

items: Aberrations and Beasts
Beasts and Fey
Beasts and Fiends
Beasts and Undead

entries.name: Familiar Powers
entries: Some familiars may have {@i extremely} powerful abilities that can be problematic if left unchecked—gibbering mouthers, nothic insight, sea hag death glares, etc.
A familiar can't cast spells nor spawn copies of itself. In addition, the GM may—at their discretion—choose to fuel, limit, or void any ability they consider game-breaking:

items: {@b Fuel:} The familiar's summoner must spend one spell slot each time this ability is used.
{@b Limit:} This ability can be used only once, regaining expended uses when the familiar is re-summoned.
{@b Void:} The familiar can't use this ability.

entries.name: Mutations
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 3rd Level}
Whenever you summon your familiar, you may choose one of the following mutations:

entries.name: Air is for the Living
entries: Your familiar does not need to breathe.

entries.name: Bound by Blood
entries: Whenever your familiar is reduced to 0 hit points, you can spend one hit die to reduce your familiar to 1 hit point instead.

entries.name: Fly My Pretty
entries: Your familiar gains a flying speed of 40 feet.

entries.name: Shared Power
entries: If your familiar forces a creature to make a saving throw, it uses your spell save DC.

entries.name: Silver Claws
entries: Your familiar's weapon attacks are considered magical for the purpose of overcoming immunity and resistance to nonmagical attacks.

entries.name: Under the Sea
entries: Your familiar gains a swimming speed of 40 feet.

entries.name: Familiar Telepath
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 5th Level}
You can communicate telepathically with your familiar and perceive through your familiar's senses as long as you are on the same plane of existence.
While perceiving through your familiar's senses, you can speak through your familiar in your own voice—even if your familiar is normally incapable of speech.

entries.name: Mutation Master
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 7th Level}
Whenever you summon your familiar, you can choose two mutations to apply to it.

entries.name: Chain Tyrant
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 9th Level}
You can spend your bonus action to command your familiar to make one attack.

optionalfeature.name: Pact of the Tome
entries: You ask your patron for forbidden knowledge, and are rewarded with a tome of eldritch secrets.

entries.name: Book of Shadows
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 1st Level}
You gain a book of forbidden knowledge from your patron, granting you more power over the arcane.

entries.name: Adding Rituals
entries: When you find a ritual spell, you can add it to the book if the spell's level is equal to or less than half your warlock level (rounded up).
For each level of the spell, you must spend 2 hours and 50 gp for the rare inks needed to inscribe it.

entries.name: Book of Shadows
entries: An eldritch book of forbidden knowledge. While you are holding your Book of Shadows, you can cast your warlock spells as a ritual if they have the ritual tag.
Your book bears the unmistakable mark of your patron—fiendish red veins, fey vines and flowers, aberrant runes and etchings, etc.

items: {@b Forbidden Cantrip:} Choose one cantrip from any class spell list. While the book is on your person, you can cast that cantrip at will. It doesn't count against your number of cantrips known.

{@b Forbidden Ritual:} Choose one 1st-level spell that has the {@i ritual} tag from any class spell list. The spell appears in the book and doesn't count against the number of spells you know. While the book is in your hand, you can cast that spell as a ritual.

entries.name: Forbidden Knowledge
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 3rd Level}
Add two additional cantrips and one additional 1st-level spell that has the ritual tag to your {@i Book of Shadows}. These spells can be from any class spell list (and needn't be from the same list).

entries.name: Page of Eldritch Power
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 5th Level}
A new page appears in your Book of Shadows—a page of eldritch power. Choose a power from the options below.

entries.name: Adding Names:
entries: A creature may spend an action to write its true name on the page. The page can contain a number of names equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1)—additional names (or false names) written on the page will fade after one minute.

entries.name: Removing Names:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you may touch one page of power from your {@i Book of Shadows} and magically erase any names of your choice.

entries.name: Destroying the Page:
entries: The page naturally heals any damage to it. If the page is torn out of the book, that page turns to ash and a new one appears in the book—exactly as it was.

entries.name: Mind Palace
entries: You can cast the {@spell Sending} spell, targeting a creature whose name is on the page, without using a spell slot and without using material components. To do so, you must write the message on the page. The target hears the message in their mind, and—if the target replies—their message appears on the page rather than in your mind. The writing disappears after 1 minute.

entries.name: The Patron Knows All:
entries: Your patron is fully aware of any message sent or received by your Book of Shadows.

entries.name: Deathly Note
entries: When any creature whose name is on the page is reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, the creature magically drops to 1 hit point instead.
Once this magic is triggered, no creature can benefit from it until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: The Patron's Price:
entries: If a creature dies while their name is written on the page, their soul is claimed by your patron and you regain one expended spell slot.

entries.name: Focused Mind
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 7th Level}
While you are holding your {@i Book of Shadows}, you have advantage on Constitution saving throws that you make to maintain your concentration on a spell.

entries.name: Achivist
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 9th Level}
Your {@i Book of Shadows} gains another page of eldritch power. Choose a power—you may take the same option multiple times if you wish.

optionalfeature.name: Pact of the Wand
entries: You ask your patron for the power to destroy, and are rewarded with an eldritch wand of devastation.

entries.name: Wand of Devastation
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 1st Level}
You gain a sinister wand from your patron through which you can harness their limitless, destructive power.
While you are holding your pact wand, you can cast the {@spell Eldritch Blast} cantrip at will.

entries.name: Wand of Devastation
entries: A wand of eldritch power. This wand crackles with strange energy and is unmistakably {@i otherworldly} in origin, bearing all the hallmarks of your patron—fiendish red veins, fey vines and flowers, aberrant runes and etchings, etc.

entries.name: Eldritch Blast

items: {@b Casting Time:} 1 Action
{@b Range:} 120 feet
{@b Components:} V, S
{@b Duration:} Instantaneous

entries: A beam of crackling energy streaks toward a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d10} force damage.

entries.name: Greater Eldritch Blast:
entries: Starting at 3rd-level, once per turn when you hit a creature with eldritch blast, you can add your Intelligence modifier to the damage.

entries.name: Superior Eldritch Blast:
entries: (5th-level) You can choose to attack two separate targets. Make a separate attack roll for each target.

entries.name: Wand Powers
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 3rd Level}
Choose one of the following wand powers. Whenever you finish a long rest, you may change your wand powers.

entries.name: Chilling Blast
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a creature with eldritch blast, you can chill it. That creature's speed is reduced by 10 feet (to a minimum of 5 feet) until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Decaying Blast
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a creature with eldritch blast, you can leave a lingering decay. That creature can't regain hit points until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Grasping Blast
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a creature with eldritch blast, you can pull the creature 10 feet towards you in a straight line.

entries.name: Marking Blast
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a creature with eldritch blast, you can mark it with glowing energy. Until the end of your next turn, that creature can't benefit from the {@condition invisible} condition.

entries.name: Repelling Blast
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a creature with eldritch blast, you can push the creature up to 10 feet away from you in a straight line.

entries.name: Seeking Blast
entries: Once per turn, when you attack a creature with eldritch blast, you can ignore the effects of half and three-quarters cover.

entries.name: Shocking Blast
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a creature with eldritch blast, you can shock it. That creature can't take reactions until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Greater Devastation
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 5th Level}
Choose one additional wand power.

entries.name: Destruction
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 7th Level}
While you are holding the wand, you can spend an action to cast {@i Destruction} as a 5th-level spell.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Destruction

items: {@b Casting Time:} 1 Action
{@b Range:} Self
{@b Components:} V, S
{@b Duration:} Instantaneous

entries: Scattering beams of destructive force erupt from your wand. Each creature in a 60 foot cone must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 8d6 force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Any creature that is reduced to 0 hit points by this spell is disintegrated.

entries.name: Disintegration
entries: {@i You gain this Pact Feature at 9th Level}
While you are holding the wand, you can spend an action to cast {@spell Disintegrate} as a 6th-level spell.
You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Armor of Shadows
entries: You can cast {@spell Mage Armor} on yourself at will, without expending a spell slot or material components.

optionalfeature.name: Beast Speech
entries: You can cast {@spell Speak with Animals} at will, without expending a spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Beguiling Influence
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Deception} and {@skill Persuasion} skills.

optionalfeature.name: Devil's Sight
entries: You can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 120 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Eldritch Sight
entries: You can cast {@spell Detect Magic} at will, without expending a spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Eyes of the Rune Keeper
entries: You can read all writing.

optionalfeature.name: Fiendish Vigor
entries: You can cast {@spell False Life} on yourself at will as a 1st-level spell, without expending a spell slot or material components.

optionalfeature.name: Gaze of Two Minds
entries: You can use your action to touch a willing humanoid and perceive through that creature's senses until the end of your next turn.
As long as the creature is on the same plane of existence as you, you can use your action on subsequent turns to maintain this connection, extending the duration until the end of your next turn.
While perceiving through the other creature's senses, you benefit from any special senses possessed by that creature, and you are blinded and deafened to your own surroundings.

optionalfeature.name: Mask of Many Faces
entries: You can cast {@spell Disguise Self} at will, without expending a spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Misty Visions
entries: You can cast {@spell Silent Image} at will, without expending a spell slot or material components.

optionalfeature.name: Otherworldly Leap
entries: You can cast {@spell Jump} on yourself at will, without expending a spell slot or material components.

optionalfeature.name: Thief of Five Fates
entries: You can cast {@spell Bane} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Mire the Mind
entries: You can cast {@spell Slow} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: One with Shadows
entries: When you are in an area of dim light or darkness, you can use your action to become {@condition invisible} until you move or take an action or a reaction.

optionalfeature.name: Sign of Ill Omen
entries: You can cast {@spell Bestow Curse} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Bewitching Whispers
entries: You can cast {@spell Compulsion} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Dreadful Word
entries: You can cast {@spell Confusion} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Sculptor of Flesh
entries: You can cast {@spell Polymorph} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Ascendant Step
entries: You can cast {@spell Levitate} on yourself at will, without expending a spell slot or material components.

optionalfeature.name: Minions of Chaos
entries: You can cast {@spell Conjure Elemental} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Whispers of the Grave
entries: You can cast {@spell Speak with Dead} at will, without expending a spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Vulture's Eye
entries: Paranoia clutches and binds itself to your mind, heightening your senses. You gain proficiency in the Investigation and Perception skills.

optionalfeature.name: Eldritch Tendrils
entries: The sinister and warped appendages of something impossible burst from you, trampling the insignificant. You can cast {@spell Arms of Hadar} at will, without expending a spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Jaws of Impending Doom
entries: You've learned to summon a portion of some bewitched domain for brief instances, and expose your enemies to a fraction of it. You can cast {@spell Hunger of Hadar} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: The Unnameable
entries: Just as you've seen horrors incomprehensible to the human mind, your patron has granted you access to subject others to similar realizations. You can cast {@spell Phantasmal Killer} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Cosmic Insight
entries: Your connection to a cosmic entity grants you access to immense knowledge beyond mortal comprehension. You can cast {@spell Divination} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Extrasensory Despair
entries: You have managed to conjure a rudimentary image of some portion of your patron for your enemy to gaze upon. You can spend one hit die to cast {@spell Mental Prison|XGE} at 6th level without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Mind's Eye
entries: You can sense a creature's intent. You gain proficiency in the Insight and Perception skills.

optionalfeature.name: Fluctuating Energy
entries: After you finish a short or long rest, swap one of your saving throw proficiencies with another random one.

optionalfeature.name: Eldritch Strike
entries: You can expend a spell slot to roll your Cultists die and make a melee spell attack. On a hit, the target takes force damage equal to the roll result plus your proficiency modifier. If your roll result is low, {@b sacrifice} some cultists.

optionalfeature.name: Your Life is Mine
entries: You can roll your Cultists die to gain twice the roll result in temporary hit points, {@b sacrificing} some cultists in the process. You can't do this again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Fortress of Flesh
entries: You can burn a hit die to roll your Cultists die and raise your AC by the result until the start of your next turn. If your roll is low, {@b sacrifice} some cultists. You can't do this again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: The Power of Many
entries: You can roll your Cultists die to cast any spell you know and have prepared without burning a hit die or spending a spell slot. If your roll is high or low, perform {@b two sacrifices}.

optionalfeature.name: Actions Unmade
entries: You can cast {@spell Temporal Shunt|EGW} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Blessing of Sylph
entries: You can spend one hit die to cast {@spell Investiture of Wind|XGE} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Courtier
entries: You know how to survive at court, mundane and magical. You gain proficiency in the Deception and Insight skills.

optionalfeature.name: Fey Magics
entries: You can cast the following cantrips: {@spell dancing lights}, {@spell druidcraft}, and {@spell friends}.

optionalfeature.name: Fey-like Being
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and magic can't put you to sleep.

optionalfeature.name: Misty Escape
entries: You can vanish in a puff of mist in response to harm. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to turn invisible and teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space you can see. You remain invisible until the start of your next turn or until you attack or cast a spell. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Devil's Flock
entries: You can cast {@spell Dominate Beast} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Fiendish Flesh
entries: You can spend one hit die to cast {@spell Investiture of Flame|XGE} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Fiendish Senses
entries: You can cast {@spell Detect Evil and Good} at will, without expending a spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Fiery Tongue
entries: You know how to get people to do what you want. You gain proficiency in the Intimidation and Persuasion skills.

optionalfeature.name: Hell's Quarrel
entries: You can cast {@spell Flame Arrows|XGE} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Hellish Companion
entries: You can cast {@spell Infernal Calling|XGE} without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Blast Bones
entries: When one of your greater skeletons dies you can choose to have it explode dealing necrotic damage to each creature in a 10 ft. radius. This damage equals {@damage 1d6} + your Warlock level. This destroys the greater skeleton completely, leaving no bones to reanimate.

optionalfeature.name: Eldritch Empowerment
entries: Your greater skeletons can use your Charisma modifier instead of their Strength or Dexterity for attack and damage rolls.

optionalfeature.name: On a Pale Horse
entries: You can cast {@spell Find Steed} without expending a spell slot. The steed is undead instead of its normal type. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Undying Focus
entries: You can maintain concentration even while incapacitated. If you fail a death saving throw make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw with disadvantage to maintain concentration on the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Spectral Sight
entries: You can see {@condition invisible} creatures. Additionally, you can see into the Ethereal Plane out to a radius of 30 ft.

optionalfeature.name: Command the Dreadhorde
entries: You can cast {@spell Animate Dead} as a 6th-level spell without expending a spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Hunters Prowess
entries: You gain proficiency in the Survival and Nature skills.

optionalfeature.name: Quick Draw
entries: You have advantage on initiative rolls and cannot be surprised.

optionalfeature.name: Thrill of the Hunt
entries: When you kill a creature you may give yourself advantage on one ability check, saving throw, or attack roll within the next minute.

optionalfeature.name: Arcane Disengage
entries: When you take damage, you can use your Reaction to magically teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see. Additionally, you reduce the triggering damage by an amount equal to your warlock level. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Call of the Wild
entries: You can cast {@spell Conjure Animals} without spending a spell slot once per long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Eye for the Hidden
entries: You can cast {@spell see invisibility} at will, without expending a spell slot.

action.name: Aim
entries: If you haven't moved since the start of your turn, you have advantage on the next attack roll you make before the end of your turn. In addition, your speed is reduced to 0 until the end of your turn.

variantrule.name: Wild Shape
entries: As a druid, you are able to tap into the primal essence of wild beasts. Use your primal power to shapeshift into animal forms and defend the wilds with savage fury.

entries.name: Your Wild Shapes
entries: A wild shape is a magical merging of a primal essence, a beast skin, and your own druidic characteristics and personality.

entries.name: Primal Essences
entries: At the heart of every wild shape is a {@i primal essence}. It is this essence that defines the primary abilities, defenses, and basic traits of your wild shape. At 1st-level, you know three common primal essences of your choice. You learn additional essences of your choice at higher levels as shown in the {@i Primal Essences} column of the Wild Shape table.

entries.name: Replacing Known Essences:
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can choose one of your known essences and replace it with a different option.

entries.name: Primal Skins
entries: Primal skins defines what you look like—cat, bear, unicorn, frog, etc. They also define the capabilities—and limitations—of your wild shape. Cats have claws, birds fly, horses gallop, etc—be creative with the natural features of your beast skin.
At 1st-level, you know two common primal skins of your choice. You learn additional skins of your choice at higher levels as shown in the {@i Primal Skins} column of the Wild Shape table.

entries.name: Size Categories:
entries: Each skin that you learn has a size category—tiny, small, medium, etc—that matches the size of the beast you learned the skin from. The larger your wild shape is, the more formidable you are—but the more primal power you must spend to take on the wild shape.

entries.name: Replacing Known Skins:
entries: You can replace your known primal skins by studying beasts and mastering their form. See {@i Primal Skins} for more details.

entries.name: Primal Traits
entries: Primal traits enable you to customize your wild shape feature to better suit your own druidic interests—talking while shapeshifted, changing your appearance, gaining more primal skins, etc.
At 1st-level, you know one primal trait of your choice. You learn additional traits of your choice at higher levels as shown in the {@i Primal Traits} column of the Wild Shape table.

entries.name: Shapeshifting
entries: During your turn, you can spend an action to take on a wild shape. There are four basic steps to shapeshifting:

items: {@b Your Essence:} Choose one primal essence from your list of known essences. Change your own AC, speed, and size to match your essence, and add any skills and traits you gain.
{@b Your Skin:} Choose one primal skin from your list of known skins. Make sure to pick one that is appropriate for your essence.
{@b Your Size:} Choose the size category that matches your skin and update your AC, speed, and unarmed damage.
{@b Spend Primal Power:} Finally, spend your primal power to assume your wild shape.

entries.name: Appearance
entries: When you shapeshift, you don't become an exact copy of your primal skin. Instead, there is something personal and unique about your wild appearance—fur pattern, horn shape, eye color, etc.

This is usually a feature carried over from your natural appearance as you shapeshift—whether you want it to or not. Most druids have one notable quirk that persists across all their shapeshifted forms.

entries.name: Duration
entries: You can remain shapeshifted for one hour, at which point you revert to your normal form automatically unless you expend additional primal power to maintain your shape.
You can also revert to your normal form by (a) spending a bonus action on your turn to end the effect, (b) falling unconscious, or (c) falling to 0 hit points.

entries.name: Equipment
entries: You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or continues to be worn by you.

Your equipment doesn't change size or shape to match your new shape, and any equipment that you can't wear must either fall to the ground or merge with your form. Equipment that merges with your form has no effect until you leave your wild shape.

entries.name: Hit Points & Attributes
entries: When you shapeshift, your hit points—both current and maximum—don't change. Neither do your attributes, saving throws, resistances, or vulnerabilities—unless specified otherwise in your primal essence.

entries.name: Character Features:
entries: You retain the benefit of any features from your class, race, or other source and can use them if your wild shape is physically capable of doing so. However, you can't use any of your special senses—such as darkvision—unless your new form also has that sense.

entries.name: Making Attacks
entries: While you are shapeshifted, you can make unarmed attacks using any of your wild shape's natural weapons—teeth, claws, horns, etc. You are proficient with unarmed attacks while shapeshifted.

entries.name: Spellcasting:
entries: While you are shapeshifted, you can't cast spells. Shapeshifting doesn't break your concentration on a spell you've already cast, or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a spell—such as {@spell Call Lightning}—that you've already cast.

entries.name: Movement
entries: Some beasts have special modes of natural movement—burrowing, climbing, swimming, flying, etc. However, when you shapeshift, you are limited to a walking speed as listed in your essence profile.

You may gain additional move speeds by mastering uncommon essences such as {@optfeature Essence of Flight|GCC|Essence of the Hawk}, {@optfeature Essence of Burrowing|GCC|Essence of the Mole}, and {@optfeature Essence of Climbing|GCC|Essence of the Spider}. {@note (Note: These names for the essences only appear here.)}

entries.name: Primal Essences
entries: Primal essences are at the heart of your wild shape, defining your beast abilities and traits. Essences come in two categories—common and uncommon.

entries.name: Common Essences
entries: Common essences are available to all druids—you can learn these from 1st-level.

items: {@optfeature Essence of Burrowing|GCC}
{@optfeature Essence of Climbing|GCC}
{@optfeature Essence of Defense|GCC}
{@optfeature Essence of Dexterity|GCC}
{@optfeature Essence of Disguise|GCC}
{@optfeature Essence of Hunger|GCC}
{@optfeature Essence of the Pack|GCC}
{@optfeature Essence of Speed|GCC}
{@optfeature Essence of Strength|GCC}
{@optfeature Essence of Tracking|GCC}

entries.name: Uncommon Essences
entries: Uncommon essences can't be mastered until you meet the minimum level requirements.

items: {@optfeature Essence of Flight|GCC}
{@optfeature Essence of Swimming|GCC}

entries.name: Primal Skins
entries: A primal skin defines what you look like and what you can broadly do while you are shapeshifted into a wild shape.

entries.name: Learning a New Skin
entries: To learn a new primal skin, you must carefully observe and study a beast. There are 5 steps to mastering a new shape:
{@b Choose a Beast:} Decide which animal you want to learn to shapeshift into—cat, dog, bear, etc.
At 1st-level, your primal skin must come from a tiny or small beast. Starting at 3rd-level this increases to medium size, and—from 5th-level—large size.

items: {@b Find a Living Beast:} You must now find a suitable beast to study. Depending on the rarity of your chosen beast, you may have to undertake a wild hunt to track your primal quarry.

entries: {@b Study the Beast:} Once you have found a beast, you must closely study it. This requires 1 hour of dedicated focus per CR of the beast (minimum 1 hour). If the beast is friendly, reduce the required time by half—but if it is acting hostile, double the time.
If your efforts are significantly interrupted—the beast escapes, you fall asleep, a combat encounter begins, etc—you lose your focus and must start your observations again from the beginning.

items: {@b Memorize the Skin:} Once you have successfully studied the beast and practiced its form, you can add it to your list of known primal skins.

entries: You can memorize a limited number of primal skins at any one time. When you learn a new skin and replace an existing one, the old skin is forgotten—you must relearn it if you wish to use it again in future.

entries.name: Natural Shapes
entries: You can't learn a skin from a shapeshifter or any creature that is not at its natural size—such as those affected by the {@spell Enlarge/Reduce} spell.

entries.name: Rarities
entries: Primal skins can vary in rarity from common to legendary. These exceptional skins bear unusual features that make them stronger, faster, or more resilient—bone-plated skin, volcanic breath, elemental feathers, superior claws, etc.
When you shapeshift into an uncommon, rare, or legendary primal skin, add the skin's rarity bonus to your AC, attack rolls, and damage rolls.

entries.name: Primal Traits
entries: As you gain druid levels, you develop more control over your ability to shapeshift with primal traits.

entries.name: Natural Power
entries: Your primal power capacity increases by +2. You may take this trait multiple times, increasing your capacity by +2 each time.

entries.name: Natural Understanding
entries: Your primal essence capacity increases by +1. You may take this trait multiple times, increasing your capacity by +1 each time.

entries.name: Primal Affinity
entries: You develop a primal affinity for a new type of skin. You can take this trait multiple times, choosing a new monster type each time.
Although this trait allows you to learn new skin types, you remain unable to master the primal skin of any creature that is a shapeshifter—changelings, mimics, doppelgangers, etc.

items: {@b Elemental:} Starting at 8th-level, you can master the primal skin of elementals.
{@b Dragon:} Starting at 8th-level, you can master the primal skin of dragons.
{@b Monstrosity:} Starting at 8th-level, you can master the primal skin of monstrosities.
{@b Oozes:} Starting at 4th-level, you can master the primal skin of oozes.
{@b Plant:} Starting at 4th-level, you can master the primal skin of plants.

entries.name: Shape Mastery
entries: You can control the appearance of your primal skin (to a limited degree). While you are shapeshifting, you may immediately spend a bonus action to determine notable aspects of your appearance—such as fur pattern, horn shape, eye color, etc. You can also choose to suppress any of your natural quirks that would otherwise be visible in your wild appearance.
You can't change the natural parameters of your primal skin—such as size, wings, number of legs, etc.

entries.name: Skin Memory
entries: Your primal skin capacity increases by +2. You may take this trait multiple times, increasing your capacity by +2 each time.

entries.name: Shifter
entries: You can alter your normal form to resemble one of your primal skins. As an action on your turn, choose one of your primal shapes and change your appearance to match it in some fashion—gaining horns, growing fur, sharpening teeth, etc.

This is a purely cosmetic change and has no noticeable impact on your abilities—though it may impact how other creatures react to you. The change lasts until you dismiss it on your turn as a free action, or until you fall unconscious. This does not require you to spend any primal power.

entries.name: Wild Voice
entries: While you are shapeshifted, you are able to speak as normal. The sound of your voice may change, however, depending on your form—pitch, volume, slurring, hissing, spitting, etc.
Though you can speak, you still can't cast spells—even those that rely only on verbal components.

variantrule.name: Pact Boons
entries: When you make a pact with a patron, you are rewarded with a boon—a special artifact that symbolizes the eldritch bargain that has been struck.
This chapter introduces four pact boons for you to choose from—blade, chain, tome, and wand.

entries.name: Choosing Your Pact
entries: Choose your pact from one of the following options:

items: {@b {@optfeature Pact of the Blade|GCC}:} You want physical power, and you are rewarded with an eldritch weapon.
{@b {@optfeature Pact of the Blood|GCC}:} You ask your patron for immortality, and you were rewarded with your patron's blood.
{@b {@optfeature Pact of the Chain|GCC}:} You want to control others, and you are rewarded with a familiar-summoning trinket.
{@b {@optfeature Pact of the Tome|GCC}:} You want forbidden knowledge, and you are rewarded with an eldritch spellbook.
{@b {@optfeature Pact of the Wand|GCC}:} You want to destroy your enemies, and you are rewarded with a wand of destruction.

entries: Your pact boon artifact bears the unmistakable mark of your patron—fiendish red veins, fey vines and flowers, aberrant runes and etchings, etc. You may decide how your artifact is branded by your patron.

entries.name: Sealing your Pact
entries: You gain your pact boon artifact once you seal your pact—traditionally by means of making a promise or sacrifice to your patron. Choose one of the following, or define your own sealing ritual:

items: {@b I made a promise:} You have sworn to perform a particular service in the name of your patron. Your promise should be (a) achievable and (b) narrow enough in scope so that it can be reasonably addressed during gameplay.
{@b I made a sacrifice:} You sacrificed something of great value to your patron.

entries: Describe how you sealed your pact with your patron, or pick a random suggestion (if appropriate) from the {@table Patron Promises|GCC|Promises} and {@table Patron Sacrifices|GCC|Sacrifices} tables.

entries.name: Renewing your Pact
entries: If you lose your pact boon artifact, you can spend one point of eldritch favor and perform a 1-hour ceremony to receive a replacement artifact from your patron.
This ceremony can be performed during a short or long rest, and it destroys the previous boon item.

entries.name: A New Seal
entries: Depending on the circumstances in which you lost your artifact, your patron may demand that you renew your pact with a fresh seal. This may require you to make a new promise or sacrifice.

variantrule.name: Spellscript
entries: Spellscript is an academic language of runes, glyphs, and sigils used to transcribe spells and arcane knowledge. Wizard spells and scrolls are almost always written in spellscript—it is the common tongue of the arcane.

Perhaps you were trained by a mentor, or you taught yourself through careful study of spellbooks, or a strange force burned magical words into your mind—whatever your background, spellscript is your key to arcane power.

entries.name: Your Writing Dialect
entries: Though the basic principles of spellscript are well understood, every wizard instinctively develops their own coded {@i dialect} which reflects their individual tastes and writing style—spellscript is as much art as it is science.
Choose your dialect from the {@i Spellscript Dialect} table below, or define your own style:

entries.name: Spellpaper
entries: Spellscript can only be written onto a magical surface—otherwise it begins to blur, fade, and then vanish after 1 minute. For this reason, wizards like to record their spells on specially-crafted {@i spellpaper} and bind sheets together into large, magical {@item spellbook|phb|spellbooks}.

entries.name: Magical Capacity:
entries: One sheet of spellpaper can hold up to one spell level of magic power. A 1st-level spell, for example, can be written on one sheet of spellpaper—a 5th-level spell, however, requires five sheets.

entries.name: Crafting Spellpaper:
entries: If you are trained in arcana and calligraphy tools, you can transmute a normal sheet of paper into spellpaper. It takes 1 hour to infuse a sheet of paper with 0.5 gp of arcane dust. Any content on the paper remains intact during this process.

entries.name: Spellpaper
entries: A sheet of magical spellpaper. This paper is used to record magical spells and arcane knowledge.

entries.name: Detectable:
entries: Spellpaper has a magical aura and can be detected by arcane senses (such as the {@spell Detect Magic} spell).

entries.name: Writing Spellscript
entries: Once you have some spellpaper, it's time to start writing. As a wizard, you are typically using spellscript to write something new or make a copy of an existing spell.

entries.name: Writing Something New
entries: There are times where you are struck by inspiration and want to write something new—researching a new spell, sharing arcane knowledge with another wizard, recording your own magical discovery, etc.
You must spend 1 hour and 10 gp per spell level (to a minimum of 1 hour and 0 gp) to successfully write your own original spellscript.

entries.name: Making a Copy
entries: Sometimes you want to make a written copy of a spell or a piece of spellscript writing—copying a spell from a magic scroll, deciphering an enemy's spellbook, recording some magic runes from an ancient ruin, duplicating your own spellbook, etc.
The time needed to do this depends the author of the original material and their {@i dialect} of spellscript.

items: {@b I wrote the original:} you must spend 1 hour and 10 gp per spell level (to a minimum of 1 hour and 0 gp) to successfully write the copied spellscript.
{@b Someone else wrote the original:} you must spend 2 hours and 50 gp per spell level (to a minimum of 1 hour and 0 gp) to successfully write the copied spellscript.

variantrule.name: Spellbooks
entries: No self-respecting wizard is a wizard for long without a spellbook of their very own—a priceless tome in which to record spells and arcane knowledge.

entries.name: Your Spellbook
entries: Your spellbook is a unique tome with its own decorative flourishes and margin notes.

It might be a plain, functional leather volume that you received as a gift from your master, a finely bound gilt-edged tome you found in an ancient library, or even a loose collection of notes scrounged together after you lost your previous spellbook in a mishap.
Choose a description from the table below, or define your own appearance:

entries.name: Magical Capacity
entries: Magical writing is inherently powerful, and stacking multiple spells together in close proximity—such as in a spellbook—can have unpredictable consequences.
A single spellbook can safely hold up to 50 spell levels worth of spells and arcane knowledge.

entries.name: Capacity Burnout:
entries: If your spellbook capacity is exceeded, your spellbook will purge itself and erase content at random until balance is restored.

entries.name: Spellbook
entries: A leather-bound tome with 50 blank vellum pages and 50 spellpaper pages. The pages are mottled and the cover glimmers with an ethereal light. This book can be used to record magical spells and arcane knowledge.

items: {@b Detectable:} This book has a magical aura and can be detected by arcane senses (such as the {@spell Detect Magic} spell).
{@b Capacity:} This book can hold a total of 50 spell levels worth of spells and arcane knowledge.
{@b Volatile:} If this book is carelessly destroyed, roll {@dice 1d100}—if the result is lower than or equal to the total number of recorded spell levels, it explodes with arcane force.

entries.name: Volatile Power
entries: Spellbooks contain powerful magical writing that can be very unstable when handled improperly. If a spellbook is destroyed without proper caution—such as by being incinerated—it may erupt with magical force.
Roll a {@dice d100}—if the result is equal to or less than the total number of spell levels recorded in the book, it explodes. Each creature within 30 ft must make a Constitution saving throw:
{@b If the creature fails:} it suffers {@damage 1d12} force damage, plus an additional {@damage 1d12} force damage for every 10 spell levels contained in the spellbook.
{@b If the creature succeeds:} it takes half as much damage.

entries.name: Making a New Spellbook
entries: As a wizard, you may be required to make a new spellbook for yourself—to replace a lost book, to expand your magical capacity, or to use as a backup copy of an existing spellbook.

{@b Crafting a Spellbook:} If you are trained in arcana and calligraphy tools, you can create a new spellbook by infusing a normal book with 25 gp worth of arcane dust. This requires 1 day of dedicated effort and attention, and the process turns 50 pages of the book into spellpaper.
Alternatively—if you have 50 sheets of spellpaper—you can bind them together in an appropriate fashion to create your spellbook.

variantrule.name: Spell Research
entries: As a student of the arcane, you are able to learn new wizard spells through careful study, research, and magical—oftentimes {@i dangerous}—experimentation.
Spend your downtime running experiments and expand your spellbook with new arcane knowledge.

entries.name: Performing Research
entries: A wizard knows that to learn, you must study—and that means {@i experiments}. To perform some arcane research, there are four basic steps:
{@b Define your Research Topic:} Choose a spell from the wizard spell list that you want to learn. The spell must be of a level that you have spell slots for.
The difficulty of your research is DC 5 + five times the spell level of your target spell.
{@b Setup your Laboratory:} Assemble your research equipment and laboratory. At a bare minimum, you need access to your spellbook, inks, magical components, and some privacy.

For every additional 100 gp you spend setting up your research—hiring assistants, buying components, renting equipment, etc—you gain a +1 bonus to your {@i Research Check} (limited to half your wizard level, rounded up) for the current workweek.
{@b Make a Research Check:} Once you have everything set up, you can start to run your experiments.
After one workweek has passed, make an Intelligence (Arcana) check and see the results using the {@table Spell Research Outcomes|GCC} table.

items: {@b Make a Complication Check:} Finally, roll {@dice 1d10}—if you roll less than or equal to the spell level of your research, there was a complication. Make a roll on the {@table Spell Research Complications|GCC} table

entries: Once your research is resolved, you may choose to run another experiment—if there is downtime to spare.

entries.name: Research Credits
entries: During your experiments and adventures, you may find research notes made by other wizards. These {@i research credits} can help you during your studies.
When you make a research check, you can spend one research credit to add {@dice 2d4|+2d4} to the result. For every additional research credit you spend, you gain a +1 bonus to the total result.

entries.name: Greater Researcher:
entries: Starting at 8th-level, the research you gain from your first research credit increases from {@dice 2d4|+2d4} to {@dice 2d6|+2d6}.

table.name: Patron Promises
rows: Kill an ancient silver dragon and eat its heart.
Convert the high priest of Emerset to betray his deity and serve you.
Visit the realm of Nazirun and burn the sacred Book of Ascension.
Obey every demand and serve you without question for the next 10 years.
Get the Queen of Rendeburg to pose for a portrait that I paint.
Make 1,000 people all sing your name during the Winter Festival.
Free the Dream Stalker from the depths of the Feywitch Prison.
Build a temple to you in the capital city.
Find a way to summon you into this world.
Let you take possession of my body during the night of the full moon.
Find and complete the secret puzzle box of Lamenchard's Lament.
Kill the archon of the cult that opposes you.
Recruit 1,000 new people into your service.
Create a new festival in your name that is celebrated in all Seven Kingdoms of Thendrae.

table.name: Patron Sacrifices
rows: The life of my precious pet.
This last copy of a rare, precious book.
The beating heart of a unicorn.
My ability to feel strong emotions.

table.name: Spell Research Outcomes
rows: {@b Critical Failure:} Your research causes an immediate, automatic complication. Roll on the {@table Spell Research Complications|GCC} table, resolve it, and then make a Complication Check as normal.
{@b So Close:} Gain a {@i research credit}.
{@b Success:} Your research was successful. Spend 50 gp per spell level to record your new spell in your spellbook.
{@b Critical Success:} Your research was {@i very} successful. Spend 20 gp per spell level to record your new spell in your spellbook.

table.name: Spell Research Complications
rows: {@b Destruction:} There was a small fire and you accidentally singed your spellbook—lose one random spell from your spellbook (or the spellbook itself if you have no spells to lose).

entries: {@b Noticed:} Your experiments have drawn unwanted attention from someone or something who will make your life more difficult, such as:

items: A demon.
A higher power.
A noble of the land.
A thief.
A mage hunter.
A wild monster.
A rival wizard.
A zealous cleric.
A furious druid.
An angry mob.

entries: {@b Backfire:} An experiment backfired—you now suffer from a magical affliction. For example:

items: You have turned yourself into a frog.
Your skin turns a random color.
All of your hair falls out.
Your teeth turn sharp and black.
Your head swells to twice its normal size.
You periodically vomit up living slugs.
Anything you touch turns red for 1 hour.
Your body grows a thick layer of animal fur.
Your hands are turned into crab-like pincers.
Words you speak are reversed.

rows: {@b Accident:} Your research has caused an accident—you owe {@dice 1d10*10|1d10 x 10} gp per spell level to cover the damages.

hp.special: equal to the wildfire spirit's Constitution modifier + your Wisdom modifier + five times your level in this class

trait.name: Lit
entries: Sheds bright light 15 feet and dim light another 15 feet, these distances are halved in the rain. This light is always present. The Wildfire Spirit is unsummoned if it is submerged in water or a similar dowsing liquid.

trait.name: Soul Bond
entries: The following numbers increase by 1 when your proficiency bonus increases by 1: the spirit's skill and saving throw bonuses above, the bonuses to hit and damage of its Flame Seed, and the bonus to damage of its Fiery Teleportation.

action.name: Flame Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, one target you can see. {@h}{@damage 1d6} fire damage.

action.name: Fiery Teleportation (Recharges after a Long Rest)
entries: The spirit and each willing creature of your choice within 5 feet of it teleport up to 30 feet to unoccupied spaces you can see. Each creature within 10 feet of the space that the spirit left must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC or take {@damage 1d6} fire damage. Activating this ability requires you to spend 1 primal point.
